reviewText:
Oh Boy... where to start? As you can see, I've sunk lots of time into this game.

One of the most amazing MMO's I've ever played that has everything, yet made thoroughly unenjoyable by the mechanics, hackers, and cash cow decisions by the publisher.

Archeage has it all. PVP, PVE, Ships, Boats, Piracy, Farming, Harvesting, Crafting, player housing, good graphics and if the greedy developers weren't so well, greedy I'd still be playing.

So to the bad and why I quit.

1. Hacker & Exploits. At launch and for a few months after it, hackers were able to exploit some serious flaws in the game that allowed them to become super super wealthy whilst legitimate players struggled.  This shafted the economy which as of now (March 2015) is in one hell of a mess with everything on the AH incredibly expensive.  Hackers were able to land grab very early on and as land was in such high demand, people would pay silly money for a small farmhouse.  It's only now due to the fact most people have left the game that land is available all over.

3. Labor. In this game if you want to do anything related to farming, you spend labor points which once spent, regenerate over time. Now here's the giggle. If you log off, overnight you will generate enough labor points for around 10 mins of farming.  If you stay logged on, permanently, you'll gain double.  This system is designed to make money from the Korean player base who pay per hour for internet use. It has no place in the western market.  It's the main reason I quit the game.

4. Gear. The best gear is crafted. Unfortunately the crafting system is so RNG based the only way you'll get gear is to buy it but because the economy is so borked, the good gear is so rediculously priced it's unreachable for the majority of players. I worked out that one bow was around £600 real money if you bought enough apexes to buy it.  Generating that kind of income can only be achieved via hacking.  What this ultimately has lead to is a small majority of players with the gear being able to one shot people in PVP.

5. Cash Cow Attitude .Going back to point 3. Run out of labor? No problem, you can buy a Labor pot from the cash store or for around 100 gold on the AH.  Want to improve your gear, you'll need to play the RNG game with uber rare items. Don't worry though you can buy these uber rare items from the cash shop.. Want to sell your property? You'll need some appraisal tickets available from the cash shop.  Want that awesome weapon? Buy APEX from the cash shop and sell in game for gold.... The list goes on.

6. The don't like constructive feedback if it's not positive.  I made only 2 posts on their forums, one was about how the labor system was hurting the game and driving players away. A couple of weeks later I tried to log into the forums and found my forum account had been 'permanently' banned. lol...  I created a support ticket which 2 months later is still unanswered. lol  This for me was actually the straw that broke the camels back and 3 days ago, reluctantly I cancelled my 4 accounts.

7. Epic player abandonment. I've never experienced such an over subscribed game at launch which became void of players within 6 months. At the start the you had to queue for hours to get on. Land was so in demand, some folks after 3 months still could not find any free. Property was sold for silly amounts.  Every square inch of farming land was occupied. Fast forward 6 months later and land is available everywhere.  Go to arena and it's the same OP geared players over and over.

8... I could go on.

9... I could go on

10. I've lost motivation to continue listing the reason this game is one to avoid.

All in all Archeage is a truly ground breaking MMO that is a victim of poor management and greed. It's such a shame because in the right hands this would be an MMO to invest all your time in.

Seriously, just avoid it and spare yourself the inevitable pain and frustration that will come from playing this game.

reviewText:
It pains me to write this review, but after 1,000+ hours and two toons leveled to max I think I'm in a safe place to critique ArcheAge. Simply put, this is simultaneously one of the most enjoyable and detestable games I've played. It has a huge open world, without loading screens (aside from the dungeons),  complete with soaring, climbable mountains and vast, mysterious oceans. It has a deep and rewarding farming/crafting system, with optional trade-runs to distant regions and continents. When you build your first boat, you feel like you have built a boat with your sweat and tears. When you complete that long trade-run to Freedich Island unmolested, its amazing. When you find someone fun and civil to run around with hunting for sunken treasure, its a great laugh. There are periodically re-spawning world bosses for all the fight against and fun little seasonal events (which usually give out rubbish freebies, but that’s neither here nor there. Its the thought that counts). Somewhere, deep inside ArcheAge there is a really, really good MMORPG.

But then, there is a dark side to ArcheAge.

- It is a Korean Free-to-Play title hobbled by unreasonably grindy, gambling-centric, cash-grab nonsense. The RNG element of this game is simply breath-takingly awful. Success rates for upgrading equipment are so low that you won't even bother grinding for the huge amount of in-game gold required. Purchasable items offered to supposedly increase your chances seem to be utterly worthless and suspect. So, in response to the horrible mess which is regrading, some players prefer to take out their credit cards, purchase a load of labor point restoration potions from AA's cash shop and then sell them in the Auction House for in-game currency. They can then purchase whatever super-weapon they desire from auction. Amazing, right?

- Everything, everything, requires painfully-slowly regenerating labor points (LP) - from opening coin purses, crafting, foraging, farming, mining, logging trees, identifying gear, doing trade-runs, and even ransoming lost XP when killed in PVE (!). The amount of LP used is proportional to the level of enemy you kill and regenerates painfully slowly. To rub salt in the wound, unless you have a subscription, its going to only regenerate when you're logged in. Subs also receive twice as much LP than free players. But either way, you'll find yourself routinely hobbled and prevented from making full use of the game’s economy, accumulating or throwing away loads of gold pouches and unidentified equipment. Because…

- Inventory/warehouse space is extremely limited and there is no way to purchase additional space outside the Auction House or the cash shop (!!). Needless to say, this feeds once again into the ‘Pay to Win’ problem, because inventory expansion scrolls are bought from the cash shop using real money and sold in-game for virtual currency. At 129-200 in-game gold per upgrade scroll, you can make a tidy profit and gain a solid advantage over the poor souls grinding away for pennies.

- The community. Man, what can I say about the selfish, sub-human specimens which dwell in ArcheAge's 'Faction' chat? Lots of unpleasant, trolling, often genital-related, angry, racist garbage in there. Don't bother asking for help, you'll get promptly ridiculed by barely literate pond-life. Alternatively, you'll just get ignored, which seems to be pretty common too (and preferable). Sadly, most guilds aren't much better. Do not trust anybody. Period. For example, if you're doing trade-pack runs, watch everyone regardless of faction. Your own guys will, without hesitation, turn on you, kill you, and steal your trade-packs. Said individuals will then be rewarded by joining the game's 'pirate faction' where they can troll and gank with absolute freedom. Don't expect the game's 'justice' system to help either. Violators are rewarded and punished by the whims of the randomly selected jurors, who are often amusingly related to the offender by guild affiliation. Trading via chat is also strongly discouraged, as glorified phishing is rampant.

- The PVP. Want to have a one-sided battle against people who have been accumulating powerful equipment for several years? Want to be one-shotted by an immortal übermensch who mightily wields the power of his magical, enchanted credit card? Sure you do! Everyone loves unbalanced, frustrating PVP. This might have been fun when the game was in beta, long ago. It isn't anymore. Whether it be the 1v1 arena or large-scale battles, you don't stand a chance against people who have either been extremely lucky with the insane RNG system or have paid for equipment.

This is by no means an exhaustive list of the crap ArcheAge’s developers have tainted their product with, but it gives you a very brief summary of the highlights (or should that be the lowlights?). I cannot in good conscience recommend this game in its current state – there are just too many serious problems baked into the game to say that it is worth investing a lot of time, energy and cash into (and boy, do its developers want you to invest that). If you just want to fire it up, create a ninja mage with jiggling boobs, and briefly explore the world of ArcheAge, sure knock yourself out. But if you want to take it seriously and invest in it, please don’t bother– it will leave your bank account and your soul very empty in the long-run.

reviewText:
This game is the perfect example of tons of potential with a horribly flawed execution.

What you expect
Incredible mix & match combat system involving combining various kinds of spellsets to create your own dynamic playstyle
A wonderous epic adventure, accomplishing quests, traversing the world by land, sea and even air
Carve out your own little piece of the world and place your house in public for all to see
Crafting/Harvesting system that also takes place in the open world
Wow! What a great list of features! I was sold on this game right away, even made the decision to go in on Archeum. Let's see how that turned out:

What you get
You know what I was hyped about? Making a guy who absolutely destroyed everything while nicely playing a banjo/flute to aid in my path of destruction. What ArcheAge delivered was one or two good combinations that could basically one-shot any other player. I desperately held on to the thought that this wasn't the case for the longest time out of everyone in my group and simply found myself worthless because I didn't spec into a specific set of spells.
Yep, you can go from point A to point B pretty plainly. Walking is well implemented. Oh, sorry, you were interested in flying and boating? So flying is alright. Unless you get a top-tier glider, you are stuck with basically just a glider, meaning you need to be generally above where you want to end up and do typical glider controls to get where you want to go. Now sea travel. Sea travel involves getting utterly destroyed by pirates and hilariously powerful sea creatures and not much else unless you voyage out at max level.
HAH. So you want a house? Tough. This game is plagued by bots and hackers. As soon as any plot of land becomes available for a house/farming plot to be placed on it, a bot or hacker owns it. Literally instantly. One of my friends bought an auto-clicker mouse to try to get our group a house after a week of playing and not even that stopped the nearby hackers who had already claimed 8 houses that day. Now you're thinking Oh

reviewText:
Take a peek at my game hours, you can bet I know a lot about this game inside and out.

If you are looking for an MMO to get into, don't get into this one. Its extreamly pay to win.

Pros:
- Trade System (Not player to player, but you make an item in one province and move it to another for money)
- Naval System (Very interesting boyancy system, fairly fun naval combat)
- Castles (Custom built castles on the northern continent that gives land to the owners)
- Land (You can own your own plot of land....or plots)
- Farming (You can grow everything you possibly need on your land)
- Class System (Or lack thereof, you can freely change between any class at any time, no new characters or anything)

Cons:
- Labor (A finite resource that grows very slowly and is needed for every single thing in the game)
- Trade System (It takes a long time, you dont make as much money as you think and it costs a ton of labor)
- Naval System (Does not exist outside a weekly pvp fight that lasts 30 minutes, and its extramly one sided)
- Castles (Theres never any seiges, its always abandoned and no one uses the land)
- Land (Too many land hackers, not enough land for 3/4 the population)
- Farming (Its not really that profitable, and costs tons of labor and needs a lot of time to grow, also you need land)
- Class System (It costs money that very hard ot get becasue of the above points to change classes at all)
- Crafting System (You need ot craft armor, break it down so you can craft another armor almost 100 times over)
- Regrade System (A month grinding gold, 90% fail rate, 5% degrade rate 5% success, wasted in 5 minutes for nothing)
- Friendly PvP (Abused heavilly, your own nation is more dangerous to you than the enemy nation)
- Playerbase (Highly hateful playerbase, also extreamly greedy, only your guild will help you.....maybe)
- World Events (Costs labor for minor gain, primarilly cosmetic in nature)
- World Edges (If you have a trade pack and go to a world edge, you lsoe it, no compinsation)
- Gear Breaking (In regrading, the expencive gear can break on you with little to no compinsation)
- Gearscore (You would need to spend $4,500 USD (Not exadurated) to compete, its extreamly unbalanced)
- Pay to Win (Every orfic of this game screams pay to win, you can't do anything without real money...lots of it)

While I did enjoy the game for a while, there is only thing that really made me quit this game, and its the regrade system. You can buy charms and better scrolls for the Chance" of a better outcome
recommended: your gear breaks and degrades just as fast as if you didn't have it. You can end up spending 8 hgours a day for a month grinding money to get the scrolls and gold enoguh to pay for the regrades

reviewText:
I was super into ArcheAge back when it came out.
I loved the concept; I loved having a farm, and fighting pirates, and mix and matching classes, I didn't even mind the subscription paywall to be able to do all those things.
However, right out of the beta gates Trion seemed almost to intentionally be sabotaging the game.
They withheld content to milk the over priced ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t in the cash shop that they expected you to regularly pony up for, as well as a monthly subscription, they even removed content after it was already in just to screw with people working for it. They held back important gameplay fixes that had been in the Korean version for over a year.
Every decision, every patch could only be described as the publisher writing personalized ♥♥♥♥ you letters to the entire player base collectively,

That is not even dipping into Trion's abusively neglectful, and inept customer service.
My long time friend and guildmate was inexplicably tossed into a mass ban from the game one day out of the blue right off the prow of my ship in a trade run. They treated him like a criminal, barely even acknowledging any of the tickets sent on his behalf by my guild due to the fact he was not even allowed to submit one of his own. They perma banned ME from the official forums for making a post about it.
When we finally, finally got a hold of a human being they dismissively said they would review it. Nearly a month later they unceremoniously gave him his account back with some sideways false positives half apology, and zero compensation for his lost paid time, and his lost property. A few days later he just quit the game out of disgust.

About three months after launch me and the rest of my guild bailed out of the game as well; from my understanding so did most everyone else before long.

Don't even waste your time, this game is already done, and the people running it do not deserve your attention.

reviewText:
DISCLAIMER!
This game wasn't on Steam the whole time I played it. I have atleast 1k hours on it.
Steam says I have 5 hours or such. Please stop commenting on that. It's wrong. Thanks.

This is one of my favorite games of all time. Why the negative review?
The game is broken in so many ways. I bought the most expensive EA pack back before the game was released. Actually, my whole guild bought EA packs. So that was $200.00 I spent. Long story short, I probably spent over $1000.00 ingame. It's really easy to do. That, in fact, is the games biggest flaw. The devs want your money. I feel like they want your money before they want you to have fun. That's a huge problem. From the get go they didn't want to open more servers. They opened one after another very slowly even thought it took hours upon hours waiting in line to get into the game at launch. Then eventually all of that was fixed. Then came the hackers and bots. You could walk around and see when a house was going to expire due to unpaid taxes. Then you could camp that spot once the timer was about to run out. Low and behold... it would get sniped. Plot sniping was a problem that developed due to hackers. They could be ANYWHERE in the map and somehow snipe up that plot you were stalking faster than you could say, Ya.... NOOOO!"

Then came Hasla. Don't even get me started on Hasla. So Hasla had some of the best weapons in the game. You had to grind mobs who dropped these stone things then turn those in to create a weapon. every mob dropped one. There were about 7 different types. You generally had groups big enough so that 2 people were assigned to each type of stone. 7 stones
date: 14 people. So you had a 1 out of 7 chance of getting your stone from a mob and then a 1 out of 2 chance of actually getting the stone if yours dropped. Also
recommended: you needed 150 of them. Then a month or 2 after that
hoursPlayed: the devs released Hasla tier 2 and 3 AT THE SAME TIME. We were all sick and tired of grinding and all FINALLY finished grinding out weapons out when BOOM. Now we had to brind all over again for about 3 times the amount of stones. I think they were actually called runes. But thats not the worst part. Hasla was also contested and the reds ALWAYS seemed to own the area that you needed to turn the stones in. SO yeah. You had to grind for like 15 hours to get all your stones. Then shortly after that I think they released chrystal shores. Yeah

Too bad."

reviewText:
So, here's how this worked.

1. Hear some good things about this game.
2. Hear a LOT of bad things.
3. Got jonesing for an MMO so I downloaded it.
4. Login
5. Facial character creation is all well and good, but what is with these Asian MMOs that don't let you change your body?
6. Opening is nice, go sailing, fire cannons, fight people.
7. Get to actual game.
8. Want money? COSTS LABOR POINTS TO GET MONEY OFF OF CORPSES
9. Want materials? COSTS LABOR POINTS TO GATHER
10. Want weapons? COSTS LABOR POINTS TO IDENTIFY ITEMS
11. Want more Labor Points? YOU'RE PLAYING FOR FREE? HAHAHA 5 POINTS PER 5 MINUTES LOSER, AND YOU CAN'T GET ANY WHILE YOU'RE LOGGED OFF
12. Starting quests give me items I can't use with a free account.
13. Finally make it to level 15, can talk in faction chat. I ask for assistance.
14. Get a whisper that I should pay for the game, since I can't own land (A big draw for this game) unless I have a 'patron' account.

10/10 uninstall button works like a charm.

reviewText: I only downloaded this game on Steam to tell you not to play it.\nI played for months in Alpha and Beta. Honestly one of the best games I have ever played. reviewText:
Where to begin? Trion heavily tries to censor whistle blowers, which is a bad sign to begin with. The game has no story, which is fine, it is supposed to be a player driven world, with player lore. However, the players control over anything in this game is non existent. The Auction House where players can trade thier crafted or farmed goods to drive a stable economy is constantly manipulated by Trion and the barrage of pactches that there is no way to predict what will make you profit. One day the best armor in the game will be 25,000gold and the next it will be worth 4,000gold, its rediculous.

Every aspect of the game has the highest amount of potential but is brought to ruins by either XL or Trion poor managment decisions.

Here is a short list of some problems with the game.....

1)In korea, all customizable equipment is crafted by the artistry profession, in NA, all customizable equipment is in the cash shop but artistry still exists to craft absolutly nothing.

2)The Economy is constantly manipulated by bots and the producers dumping product at set prices directly into the player driven auction house.

3)Every patch is botched, essentially boosting small lucky groups above the rest of the player base due to glitches and exploits, such as a few hundred players recieving numerous starter packs when only purchasing one, miscoding the most crucial land claim nodes in the game so they instantly repawned at the dead player respawn, or giving rediculous compensation to players who have quit as an incentive to return such as much valued mounts, gold, and tons of other valuables.

4)RNG, its everywhere. I am a fan of RNG but not on everything! I dont need my plants to have RNG, and my drops, and my regrading, and my crafting, and my fishing, and my buffs, the list goes on and on and it can kill a players experience. MANY have left because of this alone

5)Gameplay is based on strong player population, and there isnt one. People will say there is to help draw ppl in but just as i once was, the ppl who praise this game are addicted and in denial or the top 4% who got lucky from glitches.

6)You can destroy your own ship over and over again for profit.....

7)All mounts are normalized as is everything else in the game unlike in the other versions around the world

8)All major daily events are scheduled for the middle of the day while everyone is at work, Freedich Gold Trader is at 4pm EST/1pm PST, abysmal sea is at 5pm EST/ 2pm PST and Mistmerrow is so much earlier, im not even sure when it happens......This also leads to the empowering of one group, whichever can be on at those times.

9)Trion does not care about its customers, just check the general discusions forums and youll find tons of posts with players asking for assistance from GM's and getting snotty BS responses that basically tell the players to go F yourself.

The list could go on and on with specific examples like the castle debocle, dolphingate, the archeum tree scandal, or the swindling of archeum from coinpurses by increase the drop rate but decreasing the quality of the drops, effectivly giving us less and telling us we're getting more. And that basically sums up the game right there, you'll always be told you're getting more when infact you will recieve less....or find an exploit and be rich

reviewText:
Do not mind the hours I played on steam. I played this game a lot prior to its re-release on steam.

ArcheAge. I will now try to explain ArcheAge using my personal experience in a story-like way to sum up the downfall.

So lets say we have a hype train called ArcheAge. This MMORPG train is unlike any other (supposedly) and will be the train that will pierce the heavans. Revolutionary right? So you get your ticket to board on the hype train, but what's this? There's a queue. Well that's to be expected since its the freak'n hype train that will pierce the he- wait hold up 3 hours to queue in!? Well it's the hype train so I'll wait those 3 hours. I finally get to board in and explore the wonders that this game provides. Boy it sure is packed in the passenger peasant free to play seats... I wonder what the 1st class patreon carriages are like? Oh that's also jammed packed and had a queue. Okay. So I try to wander about and do my begginer quests to level up and stuff but since so many people where jammed packed at the start it was hard to kill basic mobs. After managing to part away form the giant cluster-♥♥♥♥ horde and moving on up the train, that was still hyped, I managed to do quests normally without the fear of being KSed. Bumpy start for the hype train but it was still good and...wait a miute, who the ♥♥♥♥ names them selves Kkknnnjjj,Hjkhjkhj, and sdfesdf. Also why are they speaking jibberish in the chat about selling me gold? These are ♥♥♥♥ing bots. Well what ever. I'm sure the conductor of the hype train will solve that issue soon right? Right!?! Anywho we move on to our quest for leveling up to 50 (as that was the max level at the time). I decided to be a Justicar because transmuting health/damage as a healer tank sounded pretty good to me. Wait what's this? A list of classses I SHOULD be so I don't insta die in pvp? Daggerspell, Darkrunner, Abolisher, Stone Arrow, ect. But what if I don't want to be those classes? Well too ♥♥♥♥ing bad cause now I suck. So half-way through leveling up I decided to be a Templar cause I like supporting my DPS friend who was a Shadow Blade. As a Templar, my specialties included t̶a̶n̶k̶i̶n̶g̶,̶h̶e̶a̶l̶i̶n̶g̶,̶ ̶a̶n̶d̶ ̶s̶u̶p̶p̶o̶r̶t̶i̶n̶g̶ ̶t̶h̶e̶ ̶t̶e̶a̶m̶  not dying as fast as other people. So onward back to being useless and needing help to finish quest cause I was KSed by superior classes. Hey what the hell happened to the train? Why are there suddenly less people? Wait they bailed out the hype train? But it's so hype. Ahh well I'm sure things will brighten up once I reach level 50 and do more interesting things such as mindlessly trading packs back and forth because I chose a terrible class to be and tried to level up my other skills. Also the exciting daily quests you do over and over and over to get gilda stars. After 50 days of doing the same thing over and over I can finally afford a boat BLUEPRINT so I can trade packs slightly faster than before. Oh I have to gather materials and use labor points to build said boat? Well okay I mean that would only make sense. Alrighty the boat's done now I can start trading intercontinentally an- You lack the sufficient labor points." Oh...w-well I guess I'll get more labor points. How do I do that again? Stand around and don't do anything labor related? Okay so being afk I guess that's not too bad I mean I'll just sit here and may- "You have been disconnected for being afk." Well ♥♥♥♥. I guess I'll have to punch this scarecrow all night while I sleep. Oh lookie I made enough labor points to have 30 seconds of labor related fun and 5% exp. Yaaay~ Well I guess while I wait for labor points to stack up again I could try to go to Hasla and farm up for good gear. Hello fellow Harranians. Wait why are you attacking me? This is your farming spot? Wait hold on can't we share? OH GOD PLEASE NOT THE SEPTER! That was the day I found out Templars are the mages ♥♥♥♥♥es. Well ♥♥♥♥ I can't farm Hasla cause I dont have good gear and I'm a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ class. I don't have good gear cause I can't farm Hasla. I guess I'll try GHA and...oh you want a Daggerspell? I'm a Templar. Oh you don't want a Templar. Oh okay bye. Uhh alright it's not all bad I mean I could just mindlessly grind those trade packs every once in a while and squeeze out as much exp possible so I can be a better class. Ummm this train is kinda getting dirty and sticky and unmaintained. I'll go check in with the conductor to see how things are going. Maybe pick up a patron along the way and hopefully make this game a little less of a chore. Sweet patron
date: now I can go out and own land and make a decent living and make decent exp at a faster rate than before and- wow do those bots claim and make houses fast. Well ♥♥♥♥ing hell. I guess with this faster labor regeneration I can level up slightly faster but I still don't have appropriate gear for ANYTHING. Sure I could craft some really good gear but I was slapped endlessly by the merciless RNGesus. Ehh things could start getting better though right? I'll knock on the door to contact the conductor of the train. Hello? Conductor Trion? You there? Huh? A note? "Thanks for the cash lol gg have fun." -XLGames. Wait wha- no...noo! Oh god the rails end at the edge of this mountain and the hype train is going to fall off. OH ♥♥♥♥ THE HYPE TRAIN IS CRASHING. Boom explosions and train noises. Those that survived the hype crash tried to make a living only to get stomped on by the far richer and much more handsome top class players who threw their cards and money as sacrifices to their unholy God known as Cash Shop. I was scared and alone trying to find someone who wasn't brainwashed into "paying to be  better than you in an online video game". Off in the distance I see a girl with luscious flowing hair and didn't have a patron mark branded on her forehead. I asked her in high hopes what her name was. She just blankly stared at me as she walked off to a random NPC. I whispered her named to my self as my last hope slowly vanished away and my sanity withered. "SDFGSDG""

reviewText:
good game but trion ♥♥♥♥ed up hard:

- pay to win, making money as a company is not a bad thing, but trion literally just tries to milk their playerbase and in return does nothing for them.... oh wait they did add more cash shop items
- economy literally got destroyed by gold sellers because trion took their sweet time releasing new cash shop items.
- hackers everywhere, which literally destroyed the whole purpose of the game, as it is a pvp centered game,
- pay to win is an understatement, it literally is exploit to win.
- kind of empty servers, some may be still active but alot a generally empty.
- Release Date: 26 Mar, 2015 as stated by Steam. This game was on steam before, selling founders pack but trion then removed the game for unknown reasons. Generally there used to be not enough comunication between trion and their playerbase, leaving a lot of frustration and making a lot of player quit.

played this game since the closed beta by buying a founders pack, glyph account got hacked, support only answered 2 months later, got a refund back then from steam. Arche Age is imho a very good game and quite fun to play, if only trion was not the publisher in the west it might have been more successful.

I really do want to recommend this game just because it actually is awesome, but trion's work as a publisher has been quite horrible as far as this game goes, therefore try this game if you insist but be prepared for a lot of frustration.

reviewText:
Do not install this game and, if you have already, follow the instructions below - this game installs a rootkit named Hackshield" which most people would not want hanging around on their machine.

http://forums.archeagegame.com/showthread.php?75534-Instructions-for-uninstalling-Hackshield

Removal Instructions:

WARNING: You should uninstall ArcheAge and Glyph before removing HackShield. While it is possible for the game to function without HackShield being enabled
date: you are guaranteed to become reinfected by it
recommended: since it will eventually reinstall itself in an ArcheAge or Glyph update.\n\nNote: People using a 32-bit operating system will see a slightly different file
hoursPlayed:
but the instructions remain the same.

Windows 8.1:
1. Right-click on your start button and select the "Run" (without quotes) option.
2. When you see the run dialog
voteText: type "regedit" (without quotes) and hit enter.\n3. Using the tree-view in the left pane
helpfulPercent:
navigate through the following folders: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE -> System -> CurrentControlSet -> Services
4. In the left pane you want to locate a folder called "XEagle64" (without quotes). Right-click on this folder and select the delete option. (May show up as "EagleX64" instead)
5. Reboot your computer.

The Hackshield service is now uninstalled and the included system driver should not run unless you try playing ArcheAge again.

Windows7:
1. Open your start menu and type "devmgmt.msc" (without quotes) into the search and hit enter.
2. On the top of this window you will see a menu entry called "View". Open this entry and select "Show hidden devices".
3. Navigate to the Non-Plug and Play section of devices.
4. Locate "XEagle64" then right-click and uninstall it. (May show up as "EagleX64" instead)
5. Reboot your computer.

The Hackshield service is now uninstalled and the included system driver should not run unless you try playing ArcheAge again.

Oh and the game also has many problems with business ethics but that is for someone else's review."

reviewText:
First off, I want to point out I've spent over 400 hrs before AA was added to Steam.

I suppose I'll start with the strong points of this game.
Graphics - it's one of the prettiest F2P games I've played. The characters look alive and distinct from each other, there are lots of animations for skills and movement. The world is colorful and delivers many pleasant views during exploration.
Crafting - it is as important as the combat, there are many branches to choose from: farming, mining, logging, carpentry, artistry, smithing etc. Crafting is rewarding both in terms of EXP and gold.
Sailing - you can build ships and use them for travel or naval warfare.
PK - some zones have open PvP, where you can kill enemies, or go rogue and kill members of your faction.
Pirates, jury and jail - if you kill too much friendlies, you go to trial. If you're found guilty by the players, you go to jail. Go to jail too many times and you get exiled from your faction and become a pirate forever.
Traderunning - make a specialty pack in a zone and deliver it somewhere else for money or special currency. The further you deliver it, the more money you get, but also you risk getting attacked by pirates.
Owning land - you can claim a piece of land and use it for crafting or you can build a house and furnish it.
Now for the bad parts...
P2W - for two reasons. First - to craft, you need Labor Points (which is like a crafting stamina). If you subscribe and get Patron status, it increases your Labor Points maximum amount from 2k to 5k, it also regenerates faster, even if you're not online. Without Patron, your crafting capabilities are really poor. You also can't own land without Patron. The second reason why this game is P2W is that it's heavily RNG. Cash shop has items that increase your chances for successful enhancement of gear. Also, if you just throw $$ at the game and sell the items for in-game gold, you can buy OP gear from the market.
Crafting becomes a chore after a while. At the beginning it's fun, but then it becomes a FarmVille experience. You're forced to log in every few hours to tend to your crops or animals. Some professions are not worth doing in terms of Labor Point/gold ratio.
RNG. Like I mentioned, the game has a randomizing aspect in gear enhancement. Same applies to drops from cash-shop chests and boss rewards. You can grind a dungeon over and over and never get the piece of armor you need. Armor also has a few grades, which makes the number of possible drops even bigger. Not to mention greedy players who will roll for every piece of gear even if they can't wear it.
No grouping mechanics. At lvl 50 you have ONE dungeon to grind for gear. And to finish it, you need a group, but you can't just hit 'find random group' button and wait, you need to spam on chat and pray to find all necessary roles.
PvP imbalance - although the game boasts 10 skillsets and hundreds of possible class combinations, there are like max 10 classes that people play because the rest are crap. All you need is a Crowd Control skill and DPS. The player who lands the hit first, wins. Also you enter the first PvP zones on lvl 30 so you need to deal with lv50s that will stalk you because you'll be an easy pray. Getting my character from lv 30 to 50 was very annoying, there's no balancing mechanic that would discourage high lvl players from ganking lowlies. I know, some people like open PvP but 1vs3 'fights' are not fair.
Stability - while the game looks and runs fine, memory leaks happen and the game is prone to crash in certain places. To start the game you need to load Glyph (Trion's launcher) first, wait for it to download files. Then you run the game, but after a 'Hackshield' (anti-cheat software) starts. Then you wait to choose the server and connect. You can then pick your character and wait for the world to load. And while EU servers run OK, US ones are often shut down temporarily.
Bots. The Hackshield does ♥♥♥♥. It doesn't prevent auto-farming bots from existing. People also hack Labor Points and teleport with tradepacks on their backs, which shouldn't happen.
Don't even try to make a traderun in the evening, all the pirate guilds will be waiting for you. Forget going solo, you need at least 10 people pt to protect your goods. Or forget your real life duties and go at 4am.

The only fun I had in this game was while getting from lv1 to 50, then it became boring. I prefer to play solo so I had nothing to do, but when I wanted to party up, I couldn't find no one. Everyone is AFKing and regenerating Labor.
Do I recommend this game? Hell no. Too much P2W, bots, hackers, scammers...

reviewText:
I am torn. Do I give this a positive or negative review? I think I'll put it down as a positive one but do not misinterpret that as me saying you should play this game.

On the one hand, I really like the game, it's fantastic, probably the best MMO I've ever played rivaling even World of Warcraft in content, replayability, level design and genuity. The game also has a lot of amazing features that most MMO's just don't have. (Court cases, sailing, own-faction-PvP, a pirate faction to name a few.) For these reasons I have trouble saying that you shouldn't play this game. The reasons why I'd give this a negative review are personal and I will explain why below.

The developers for this game do not deserve the money. I've played this game since beta, got a maxed character with level 50 in every skill and 90k proficiency in 2 skills. I had 3 large pieces of land, a galleon and a nice set of gear, and I was in many of the best guilds on the Ollo server. I was also a part of the game's first full release Kraken kill. I also want to clarify that I had well over 800 hours played in this game before the game was released on Steam.

On the release of this game, the developers promised us that the game would never come pay-to-win, and for the first few weeks it didn't. (Although that may have been because they were too busy fixing the 8 hour queue times, not an exaggeration..) But, as time went on, the developers became more and more hungry for money. Now, whether this is Trion's fault or the fault of the company that originally created ArcheAge, (XL games,) and had more creative control is up for you to decide, but either way, I am not comfortable playing a game where I am able to be so easily screwed over.

I'd love to go into extreme detail on how they screwed us over but I'm not going to, but I will mention as many as I can without being too descriptive.

First of all they brought out boxes that gave out some of the rarest materials in the game very cheaply. You could buy them for real money. (Thunderstruck logs.)

They promised us 10% off the real-money currency in-game, but didn't give us that until 4-5 months after the game was released when many players had already quit.

They sold some of the rarest armour making materials in the game for real money, (which in turn translates into in-game money.)

They made it so you get more labor whilst being online compared to being offline. (This encourages you to sit afk on the server rather than log out, hogging server space. It also means there is no incentive to take a break.)

Sold the best gliders in the game to players for 20 dollars each, and took all of the best gliders in-game with distinct advantages over these gliders and nerfed them so that people could buy the gliders without feeling like it was going to be wasted once they got an end-game glider.

They released some end-game gear to the public right as a patch was released, making the weapons people had spent thousands on almost irrelevant. (This gear was designed to be released years after the game had been released to allow new players to catch up more quickly, but Trion decided to release it 3 months after release, messing up the economy hardcore.)

Refusing to deal with land grabbers" who would hide in areas where you could build a house

reviewText: After extensive play time I can say that this game isn't a worthy MMO. While it includes many great aspects of what you would expect in a well rounded MMO it is lackluster in manyways, starting from the terrible coding to the pay to win aspect of the game. The basics that makes this game cool, such as housing/naval combat/trade runs/multi-class characters are great, but that is where it all stops. SInce this is a KMMO for some reason they expect you to sit down and spend your entire life playing the game and getting the best gear or for a small fee (credit card handy) you can easily buy some gold and have the best stuff in the game, which at that point makes you a pretty big threat because you will outgear 85% of the community and 1-3 shot most people. This is turn creates a horribly unbalanced PvP segment and in turn makes for an unfun adventure outside of protected areas, on top of that if you are attacked near neutral guards and try to defend yourself guess what! They will kill you aswell for defending against that player :) Land, what land? You mean the stuff where a bot will show up and steal from you seconds later? While I do see this game having potential, the roots are far from growing into a full tree, super grindy, buggy/memory leaking, and p2w MMO that needs a serious revamp to be competitve in the upcoming MMO market. While this game just recently came to Steam I have over 500+ hours on it off of Steam and while it is still a decently rounded game I could not see myself playing it for an extended period of time and I guess neither can my guild since 90% of the time they are standing around in Marianople. Hope you liked my review and that I hit all aspects, while I encourage everyone to try it, I just do not find it worthy of putting effort into as it is a lost cause currently.

reviewText: I wanted to love this game.  I really, really did.  So much so that I originally paid for the $150 Founders Pack.  Everything seemed amazing, and if the only factor was the gameplay and graphics, I would have loved it.  The problem soon became that this is one of the most pay-to-win games I've ever played.  I put in over 1,000 hours over the first month or so, but then things started appearing in the in-game store... RNG boxes with huge, in-game bonuses at a very low drop rate.  I'm not talking about cosmetic items, but items that were the foundation for the game's economy because they were as necessary as they were rare.  Then there was the hacking.  Land came at a huge premium and was highly coveted, however teleporting/land placement bots ran rampant.  So much so that many outwardly admitted to doing it.  From last I heard, most received 24-48 hour account suspensions.  The land they acquired they got to keep.\n\nI requested and through many emails and complaints, received a refund about a month after the game's release and haven't played since.  It's possible that everything has been fixed since then, but I highly doubt it given that the Korean version was about a year ahead of ours at the time and players there confirmed that their version was even more P2W than ours.  It's really unfortunate, because had this been a subscription-based game with no in-game store and a much stronger stance against hackers, this could have been one of the best sandbox MMORPGs of all time.

reviewText:
Please note that I have played well over the amount shown on my account. The time on Steam is from when I returned and played again for a few months.

So what is ArcheAge? A great idea executed poorly. The amount of hype for this game was immense, and when it finally dropped, well... People were angry. I was one of the people who paid $150 for the Archeum Founder's Pack, and I wish I hadn't. I have never regretted such a large purchase more than this one.

But why? Why is it so disappointing? It's advertised as the sandbox game everyone was waiting for!

Well, I'll tell you. And I'll tell you the few things it did right. Just to be generous.

Pros:
-Looks decent.
-Deep crafting system, but has drawbacks.
-You can level off of your professions. During my few month return, I went from 30-55 entirely by gathering and crafting.
-Large open world map.
-Decent character creation.
-You build your own class, but very few are actually viable.

Cons:
-Toxic community. Very toxic.
-Pay to do anything.
-The economy is messed.
-Crappy endgame. I would have quit again earlier if I didn't roleplay.
-A poorly executed player court system. Your crimes play no part in whether or not you are jailed.
-The ocean is very empty.
-There is a heavy focus on PvP, but only a few builds are viable, and credit card warriors always come out on top. There is no point in trying to enter the PvP scene now.
-Good luck trying to get land. The amount of space is very limited, and the houses are too cramped together. It doesn't look or feel natural. Claiming land is also a Patron account feature.
-Labor points.

Now let's analyze these cons. The community in this game is horrid. Actually, let me tell you a story about this.

I am a very good land grabber in this game. I have never failed to claim a piece of land the second it goes up for demolition, and the crowd that gathers for land is immense. One time, a player was attempting to grab a piece of land as well. And since it is such a desperate struggle for land, it turns every player into a savage. This person told the same lie again and again, saying that it was their family member's piece of land and that I should let them have it instead, and constantly harassed me after the fact. I saw this person saying the same thing multiple times during the same day, and was labeled by them as a part of the ♥♥♥♥ AA community" and told that I was on their guilds "KoS list". Very immature. Land grabs are fair game for anyone. If you can't log in
date: pre pay your taxes. Log in for your family member. This is the most toxic way to go about such a thing. /rantover\n\n♥♥♥♥ community aside
recommended: the pay model for this game is horrendous. Free players are simply screwed. As a free player
hoursPlayed: you cannot own land. You cannot list items on the auction house without purchase of a marketplace item. Your labor points regenerate slower and do not regenerate at all while offline. Your labor points are capped at less than half of a patron player's. You earn 20% less XP. You do not earn loyalty tokens to purchase marketplace items just by logging in. You gather and craft 20% slower. Patron accounts earn +10% more credits when purchasing. As a free player

reviewText:
-Played hundreds of hours, just not through Steam-

I WANT to like this game, I really do. That's part of the reason I'm wiring this, to finally convince myself that I should never come back to this game, which is unfortunate, because the game has a fantastic premise.

You have a massive world to explore. This includes multiple large continents, various smaller islands, the open sea, and even the sea floor. You can explore the world through various ships (from rowbots to gallions), vehicles (farm carts and sports cars), mounts, and gliders. But the best part about this massive world is everything is open to PVP between the two main continents. There’s even some ship based combat—and let me just say, you haven’t lived until you’ve dropped a meteor spell on a massive enemy ship.

Speaking of spells, how you choose to defend yourself is up to you, as your “class” is decided upon which of the 3 skill trees you choose. This means you have a total of 120 potential “classes” to choose from.

Here lie the beginnings of the sour taste left in my mouth after playing this game. You can certainly pick any class/combination of skill tress you want to, but that hardly means every class is viable much less possible. This issue here is due to the way skills derive their power from the weapons you wield. Every weapon is capable of dealing damage; however, not every weapon provides the additional buffs a class may need.

Let’s say you want to play a warrior who casts some spells on the side, then you need to find a way to work a spell power weapon into your arsenal, most likely meaning you’re now wielding a one-handed sword and an off-hand scepter for magic damage.  Or, maybe you want to be a stealthy rogue who can also do some minor healing? Well, good luck with that, because the only weapons the provide bonus healing are clubs and two-handed hammers.

While these may seem like viable alternatives to the uninitiated, they are NOT. Not only are these hybrid builds not at all viable, they’re not even marginable. By mixing classes you gimp yourself to a point where even PVE can be daunting. And GabeN help you if you attempt to mix the least-synergistic tree, ranger, with anything that wants non-range weapons.

The sourness continues into the crafting system. At first, the potential to plant and harvest crops wherever you so choose is fascinating. Though doing so will likely be your first introduction to the labor points system. To quickly summarize this system: Any planting, harvesting, or crafting requires a variable amount of labor points. Points are earned by remaining logged in; 10 points for 10 minutes. If you’re a subscriber or member then you earn double that amount per 5 minutes, with additional labor earned while not logged in. Free players can have a maximum amount of labor with subscribers having a higher cap.

So, free to play users are clearly at a disadvantage. But it doesn’t stop there. You crops, should you have the labor to plant them, can actually be stolen by both friends and enemies. This is another really cool concept that encourages exploration. Additionally, stealing crops is an in-game offence, and enough of those could land you in jail or make you an aggressive-to-everyone pirate. But again, the members have a distinct advantage when growing resources because they can actually claim land. Oh, you wanted a player owned home and special plot to grow your crops? Go pay a monthly fee. Then no one will be able to touch anything you grow in your plot.

This negative is made exponentially worse when the trade skills used for harvesting and crafting, such as woodcutting and armor smithing, require hundreds of thousands of resources to level up. So those non-members are left planting crops and hoping they don’t get stolen, and their precious labor points wasted.

Furthering this tragedy is the RNG involved in crafting. The items you make can vary in quality. Meaning if you’re hoping for a top tier quality of an item then you will likely be stuck making hundreds if not thousands of that item.
Let’s take a second to review all these labor costs while keeping in mind that you only get 5 labor every 5 minutes; plant your crop, harvest your crop (if it hasn’t been stolen), refine your materials, craft your item. If the item isn’t the quality you want: rinse and repeat. Crying optional.

Speaking of crying, the main story is also something you’ll likely cry over. Not due to its quality, but because it’s painfully short, and rather cheesy. Unless it has recently changed, the story barely carries you to half of the current level cap.
I WANT you like you ArcheAge, I really do. Your fast paced, massive PVP has made some of my best mmo memories. And your economy made me feel like I was a part of the actual world. A world I spent hours exploring and sailing in. Some of you skill trees were so cool in theory, but so lack-luster in practice. And don’t even get me started on my cow mount, Moonalisa, who has a cow pie skill.

But what it comes down to is this: ArcheAge is one giant slot machine, with your log in time being the accepted currency. You can play the odds and pay $15 a month or spend in game cash to buy membership, but that won’t change the odds so heavily stacked in favor of the house.

reviewText:
One of the best MMOs to come out for a long time.  Unforunately, it's been completey ruined by the short-sighted, money-grabbing TRION who are clearly only in it to see how much they can get out of the game before it crumbles.

F2P is an illusion - you can play for free, but you're constrained at almost every turn to the point where you have to spend $$ or quit.

P2P is also an illusion - even if you pay via APEX or subscription, you're still hampered by the labour system which charges you for doing almost anyting in the game:

Want to open a purse you just looted from a mob?  That costs labour
Want to dig up that corn you just planted?  That costs labour
Want to craft something? That costs labour
Want to mine / chop something?  That costs labour

Run out of labour - well you can wait 5 minutes for a bit more, but dig up another plant and that labours gone again.

I can't think of any other game that practically forces you to stops you doing whatever you want.

The game itself was full of hackers / bots and gold-sellers.  Whilst some of these have been addressed, many have not.  Furthermore, griefing is practically supported in this game with TRION calling it 'emergent gameplay'.

Marketplace / Cash shop items cost a fortune as they mainly in RNG boxes - I read horror stories of people begging to pay $100 for an item as a one-off cost as they've already spent $500 or more trying to 'win' it from the RNG Boxes.  The latest mess?  TRION GAVE AWAY ONE OF THOSE RARE ITEMS AS A FREE GIFT TO NON-PLAYING PLAYERS as a mean to win them back - they hacked off their own player-base and ended up having to give the item out to everyone (but no refunds for the 100's of dollars spent trying to 'win' it.

All-in-all I'm more disappointed with this game than angry.  Here was a WORLD that I was willing to spend a lot of my time in and yet TRION saw it as nothing more than a GAME CASH AND GRAB.  They would have made thousands out of me over the next few years on a regular subscription, instead they opted for a quick gain from the 'whales' and regular players like me didn't count.  So, I've quit and couldn't recommend this game for any amount of money....

reviewText:
Note: I played ArcheAge for ~300 hours, however, I didn't use steam for it.

ArcheAge is the prime example of greedy incompetent devs.

Trion is milking as much out of this game as possible, you can clearly see this with the packs they sell, some going up to 140 euro. The cash shop is huge with a lot of options that make the game terribly pay to win. Sure, you can play the game without ever spending a dime, sure, you can buy cash shop credit with ingame gold, but the prices inflated so hard after they kicked out the gold bots that I wish you good luck selling anything.

Game design wise it had a lot of potential but Trion's terrible communication and demands to the actual devs ended up with some really bad decisions. For example: they released content that was released after the release, meant for newbies to catch up with veteran players in terms of gear, at the release of the game. This meant that everyone had very easy access (or so it looks like, you'll find out eventually that it's a tiny area in the world that's overcrowded and makes you employ asinine grind and tagging tactics to get anything out of that place) to big weapons, which in turn made one of the bigger crafting professions completely useless and worthless for the bigger part.

Another big example is the total overpopulation of housing property. In the korean version of the game fewer people had membership to allow them to place houses, and the server populations were also smaller and more divided. Housing space is limited in this game and you had to compete really hard in the past to get a housing spot, a select few people used to use cheats to steal property from other players camping a decaying house to sell them. They eventually got banned, but it took a bunch of months before they did anything about it.

You need membership (patron) to maintain and place houses, so if you ever quit the game you can wave goodbye to any property you own.

The pros:
- Boat physics.
- Classes (although some will always be top tier while always wont be)
- Professions/tradeskill, although it's a typical tradeskill menu they're definitely more interesting than the cookie-cutter MMO tradeskills.
- Boat physics.

The cons:
- Weather system (I heard from rumors some sort of focus group found weather too unfun and too impactful on gameplay, and they toned down the weather from more realistic to really subtle)
- P2W (P2Advantage for you autists that take everything literal) Cash shop
- Housing system. Once you stop playing you will lose everything related to housing, and with overcrowded zones it can be hard to find a good spot again.
- Patch implementation choices and gameplay/game content changes compared to the korean version.


I honestly can't be arsed writing a bigger review than this. The game left a terrible aftertaste for me after spending so much money on it. Spending any money on anything but the subscription is a terrible waste and not worth it. And the game's flaws will eventually reveal themselves and you will hate it.

A while back Trion customer support refused to refund a patron membership purchase I misbought 3 months ago, but only activated that day, because the dates they displayed when patron would end were completely messed up and I was worried I would lose my housing properties if I didn't pay up. They literally refused to stop the patron that activated today and give me the cash shop points I used for it back.

I had fun with the game though, but I'm incredibly bitter about all the things wrong with it.

Edit:
tl;dr: ArcheAge was an incredibly fun game to me with unique mechanics that is clouded by bad gamedesign choices and Trion's terrible marketing choices and left an incredibly bitter aftertaste.

reviewText:
PROs:
Great graphics
Deep class system
Good sandbox elements

CONs:
Large pay to win aspects
Rabid housing community backed by cheaters
Ridiculous Korean influenced grind
Lack of involving endgame
Promotes player hostility
Tedious time taking activies cause game to be more like a job than a game
Greatly lacking balance

I played this game from headstart until Auroria released, so about 3 months. During that time, I have witnessed the fall of what could have been the greated MMO that ever existed. It had exactly what ♥♥♥♥♥♥mers have been asking for, it was a great sandbox. It felt a bit like a fantasy version of EVE. Needless to say, that came to an end.

It began when Trion pulled a bait and switch a few days before launch with their start pack items. It happened again a month later when Trion singlehandedly destroyed the market with the changing of the thunderstruck logs. It has happened time and time again with horrible servers during release periods like Auroria causing people to lose not only plots of land, which are essential to gameplay, but also entire castles which affect many houses in a wide plot of land.

As if the housing situation wasnt dire enough, balance is yet another aspect of the game that affirms the reasons you should avoid it. This game caters to 1 type of archetype: the archer. It has been overpowered for months and showing no signs of stopping. If you want to win at PVP, you need to be some form of an archer. Melee is underpowered and easily kited, Mages are a very strong second to archers, and by mage I mean 1 class: Daggerspell. Healers are absolutely horrible and its not possible to heal effectively and do any meaningful damage with how spell power work, not to mention nearly all the healing spells themselves are worthless. Complaints and balance issues aside, the class system is very well done and if balance wasnt such a glaring issue, the possibilites for class combination would be unrivaled....but we live in a world where balance IS an issue, so the effective class combinations go from 120 total combinations down to about 10. Yea, great job.

Trion has kept making mistakes over and over. It was a running gag between me and my friends where we just started to expect whatever could go wrong, it will, because of Trion. Granted, its hard to say what is exactly their fault and how much of the games failures is theirs or the actual Korean developer, XL Games, but from a customers standpoint, Trion is in a great place to take all the blame. However, that unrelated to the actual gameplay.

I cannot recommend this game to anyone. It has such glaring pitfalls that exemplify exactly the faults of F2P games today on the market. In fact, in my 20 years of gaming this is the first game I have ever had to do a chargeback with my bank for the misleading advertisements and bait and switch tactics employed by Trion. I downloaded this entire game from steam and booted it up for 5 minutes to write this review in hopes that it will save someone else from this MMO. Do yourself a favor, save yourself months of your time, and stay away from this game.


TL:DR: Game is pay2win nonsense, stay far away.

reviewText:
As an archeum founder alpha/ beta tester and an in-game player for almost a year to year and a half, the game was fun. The scenery was nice, game play was enjoyable, and there was always lots to do. I personally enjoyed going with guild friends on trade runs and out to sea battles.

The game began to fall apart when there were lots of gold spammers and botting cases, though that wasn't the only problem. The game focused very heavily on the Item Market section with real money. Not entirely the worst system, but made it hard for many players to get anywhere in-game without it. If ever experiencing an issue in-game or out of game, there was terrible lack of support. In fact, it was lucky to get a response back. The official launch after alpha/ beta was released, there was very little sign of patching for the the bug and glitch issues. There was also a problem regarding a botting case in-game, which caused regular players to be banned in the process for no explainable reasons. Which Trion did very little to resolve, and for some didn't do anything at all.

In my case, I was one of those few if not many to fall into the regular player category that had their account banned for no explanainable reason. I tried submitting multiple support tickets and the company was terrible at responding. Normally took weeks to get a response, and when I did, the answers were not even remotely close to what I was asking. After about ten support tickets I wasn't even able to contact them... They had restricted contact, couldn't access forums, and couldn't log into the game after spending the $150 on the game, and another $150-200 in-game.

I decided to look up Trion on the web for any traceable evidence as to whether it was happening to others as well. Sure enough, the (BBB) or Better Business Bureau has a list of complaints regarding the same issue and more. I was shocked and surprised that a company could be this bad. Since then, I haven't touched foot in ArcheAge or in any Trion games.

As a previous alpha/ beta tester and player, I would highly recommend staying away from Trion games. They do not respect their players and they have a very bad reputation for purchase history.

reviewText:
ArcheAge is both the best and worst MMO I've played. I found the gameplay and combat to be fun and intuitive. The crafting system is very intricate, the housing and farming system was well done (I like non-instanced housing, it puts more value on property. It would be better if bots didn't claim all the land right away), and the Naval combat...oh man..this is what got me hooked on the game! Sailing around the ocean looking for enemy trade ships or fishing boats, stealthing into the water and swimming up to an enemy fishing boat and stealing and and turning in THEIR fish for your profit! I was so addicted to sailing the open waters searching for prey. It was one of the best experiences I had in a game.

But now, the game is sadly dying and at a rapid pace. The game is a blatant pay to win model. It is almost impossible to obtain end game equipment without paying a lot of money. It is incredibly tedious to even play the game without paying for Patron status for your labor regen and making a lot of gold in the game is practically impossible without patron status. Sure, you can get patron with in game gold. But to get in game gold, you need Patron, See the cycle? To break the cycle, you pay real life money for patron. But you want that shiny end game Delphinad weapon? It's obtainable. But it'll cost you at least 40k+ gold for a single weapon (at the time of this review). To get 40k gold, you can grind trade runs, but you need a lot of labor and it will take about 100 days (lots of math to pull this figure). And that's IF you have patron status AND you pay real money for the farm hauler upgrade AND you grind nothing but trade runs AND you are online the entire 100 days. Labor recharge is halved if you're offline. So what people do instead is spend a lot of money on RNG boxes that contain rare items or buy APEX (what people need to get Patron) and sell for in game gold.

The entire crafting/regrading (enchanting) system is RNG based. Which wouldn't be so bad if there weren't cash shop items that increase your chances of procing regrades. This appeals to the gambling habits of people and sucks in more money. As long as you keep paying money to Trion, you can keep crafting and regrading and eventually you will proc an end game tier piece of gear. And because people spent so much IRL money to craft the gear, it sells for unreasonable and unobtainable amounts of gold on the auction house. And the cycle goes on...

So props to Trion and XL Games for destroying one of the best MMOs out there. I hope all other developers can learn from them. Your game can be amazing, but blatant cash grabs and a pay to win model WILL destroy your game.

reviewText:
Is the core game fun?
- Yes

Should you buy the game?
- No.

Problems?
1. Population imbalance.
2. New player difficulty on matured server is high.
3. Hackers killed the game. Game must be recoded to address the hacker infestation. Not a patch, a full rebuild of the game.


Concept and gameplay is really fun if you were in the early start. Even then the servers was really screwed up then with waiting time in the HOURS. That was the people that payed for the game. All the lands were already gone by the first 6 hours of the game. I had a group of friends that played this game and we were ready for the early start. We managed to throw down our farms and take up around 3072 unit of land during the first day. For the week of early access we just powered level ourselfs. Truthfully you can hit your first three level cap in one week.  Money grinding was excruciating but once we poured all our gold to obtain a single 2 slotted tractor, everyone in the group got one within 3 days.

PVP was increadibly fun and the dungeon raids were alright. We had our own ships and we went on a lot of pirating. Both allies and enemy ships were targets. We been to the enemy continent and enraged the enemy guilds to hunt us down. We had enough gold to buy each person subscription so we didn't need to pay for subscription when it expired. However we stopped playing after several weeks.

Why did we stop playing even though we can fair against pay to win players?

1. Population imbalance. PVP war? I was on the top guild on our continent and we had to fight against the biggest zerg guild in the whole game. For every 1 person on our continent, there was 5 on the other. So during the war, either we get the best guilds on our side to fight or we always lose the war.

2. Joined late, well you are screwed. Waiting for an expired land? Good luck competing against 20 people trying to grab the smallest piece of land.  Our friends that joined late have a hard time getting land. Buying land? Good luck getting one to sell at a reasonable price.

3. Hackers. The game was coded on the user end. My god, any company that is hosting the game can't do anything about it. They tanked the NPC trade market and caused inflations on the user market. They can teleport inside a terrain so you can't see their names. They just make their tradepack then teleport to the trade NPC. Then they use those gold to buy all the cheap materials and sell it for an increadibly high price. Can't buy it? Well read the spam message and buy gold with real money. PVP against hackers? You will never kill them unless they are stupid and forgot to use their hack.

reviewText:
I was a founder of this game, played the beta and hundreds of hours post-release off steam, had a guild of great people of which I eventually became an officer, and through all that I must still give it a thumbs down because of Trion Worlds who run the NA/EU servers. Getting to the endgame (lvl50-55) is a journey that is amazing your first time through, the sheer variety of quests and monsters is great, but upon reaching endgame and looking into the crafting system, you will realize this game's biggest flaw IMO.

There are 5 levels of gear for high level players, and when made they roll one of 5 or 6 types, only 1 of which can be upgraded to the next tier. Then, there are also 12 different item colors that determine quality, and you have a chance to downgrade, or even destroy the item when attempting to upgrade it. Considering you must begin with the lowest level items and craft them up one tier at a time, crafting armor and weapons is the most tedious and annoying process in the game.

While the crafting system is terrrible, most of the game is still great, from taking world bosses as combat pets to raiding ships at sea with your guild, its easy to go have fun by grabbing a friend or two and just go look for a fight or do a dungeon. Sadly as of recently I have stopped playing due to how terrible Trion Worlds is and how badly they have screwed this game up with their incessant pay2win offers, destroying and laughing at the masterful in-game economy as they flood the market with previously-rare materials and basically give no promises as to the value of anything.

Overall I still love this game, but I cannot recommend it due to Trion Worlds' idiocy, if they handed the game off to a company that understands how a game should be run i'd expect many players like me would return, but for now my sub in cancelled.

reviewText:
Oh Archeage...Where do I begin...

Pros -
-Graphics look amazing
-Diverse Costumes and Weapons
-Wonderful combat system
-No need for multiple characters

Cons -
-Literally can not play without dumping about $50 a month into the game.
-RNG system will have you ripping your hair out with a $5 chest having the chance to give you complete crap (Yes, the flight boosts)
- RNG with expensive regrading.
-Player base is more Toxic than a Twitch Passive (League fans will get that)
-Pirate and Purple faction members recieve hardly a punishment for ruining your trade run that you waited 2 weeks for (roughly..15 mins inside a prison which they can just break right out of and steal someone else's gold.)
-Plots are only available to subcribed people so that free 8x8 you get at the beginning of the game is a joke.
-Labour points make it impossible to find something to do for an extended amount of time. (A trade pack costs Labour to make AND to turn into gold! If you're out of labour by chance don't expect to make any money)
-Only way to get Labour points if you are not a subscriber is to literally AFK while you sleep by hitting on a dummy since there is a 15 min AFK kicker which Trion added after people would AFK...to get the labour they needed...to do anything in their own game...they really just took away the only way you could make a profit in the game. GG 10/10 would play again any day.
-Small amount of content
-Game is 90% PvP based and typically your faction will always lose.
-PvP is only won based off of gear score and not skill.
-In PvP there are counters for every class and more often then not, you're getting countered.
-To switch a class you have to Pay...
-To recover lost experience you must..you guessed it, pay. But wait! you pay with Labour that is based off of your level AND the level of the creature you died to!
-Land hackers and plot spammers make it hard for land trading to happen seeing as how everyone can see when a building is going to be demolished.
-Land hackers own 85% of the land
-Top level guilds have a Monopoly on trading and dungeon running.
-Unless you are in said top guild you will likely have no help with content or protection in PvP zones which you HAVE to travel through to make a good profit.

Example of your in-game, late game Regrading experience: Pay anywhere up to 900 Gold for a Superior Red Charm, 450 for a Lucky Moon/Sunpoint to increase your chances to double proc, and 45 gold for a weapon/Armor scroll. Add on to that a fee for even attempting to regrade. At the medium level of Unique (Level 5/9) this all together gives you a roughly... 30% success rate, a 10% double sucess rate, a 45% fail rate, and a 15% double fail rate. So for a Grand total of 1,400 Gold (roughly 2-3 weeks of grinding) you have a better chance of losing your current grade rather than going up. The system is in no way rewarding and gives absolutely NO COMPENSATION for those (over 95% of players) who get a DEGRADE (that's right, Trion believes in reverse upgrading) to try and work their way back up to that same point. Instead you are forced to keep your subscription rolling so you can farm your plots, store your materials, make trade packs and larders, and transport them across the ocean for the most money with the chance of: your own faction stealing from you, the enemy faction stealing from you, and pirates stealing from you. If you lose all those trade packs guess what, you get a 5% profit off of what they turn in, which usually be Gilda Stars, something that is completely worthless unless you are wanting to upgrade a house to a much larger version (The land around your house must be empty, fair warning: it never is). It is an endless loop of farming, trade running, and regrading for high level subscribers. And it NEVER pays off for the majority of players. Out of my 830 hours I spent at least 800 of them doing trade runs and PvP to try and get my trade packs back from all 3 sides. The highest level I every got to was Unique simply because I never had the money to try regrading higher. I can not tell you how much money I spent on this game trying to get to that level where most of the PvPers were, most of the Guilds who did end content even REQUIRED you to have these ridculously expensive weapons and armor so they could clear them out quickly and easily, basically making those with poor luck lose out on content.

Speaking of Content, you remember those other 30 Hours I missed out of my record? Yea thats your entire leveling experience. 30 Hours. I made it to max level in only 12 hours, the rest of it all was just side quests for money and items I could sell on the Auction. And btw, you can not fully use the auction unless you are a subcriber or use real dollars to by a liscence. You have to pay...to use an MMORPG essential...Let that sink in. I wanted to like this game, I really did but the endless grinding that never paid off simply wasn't worth it. I had friends who lost entire armor sets due to that 5% break chance above unique, it was almost like a 5% pass rate vs a 95% fail/break rate, something that should only exist at the Mythic level. This game is so pay to win that I could have paid for a majority of my college supplies with the amount of money I put into this game, hell probably even part of my tuition. The only reason to play this game is if you want a place to throw unused money at with no profit in return.

Fastest donkey in the game, cash/loyalty shop exclusive.

Crafting is stupid, roll 1-1000 and hope you roll 2, and every time you roll you spend a ton of expensive materials.
And they're running Hackshield, which is a very shady anti-cheat system almost on the level of GameGuard.

reviewText:
Ready to accept my downvotes! (since it's a negative review! woo!~)

Archeage pulled me in by offering a seemingly variety in skills/builds and being able to combat other plays in a open world, rather than in battlegrounds.

Sadly, the game mechanics are very old school. There is no active dodging/blocking/kiting/aiming/cc breaks that many newer mmo's are starting to offer. Alas, I was still willing to give the game a chance!

For convenience sake, I will break my review up into categories.

Skills:
I was very much looking forward to making diverse builds with unique skill sets! Sadly I found myself being pigeon holded into using select skills that are typically the flavor. The biggest obstacle in the way of truly being diverse are the actions bars.

While there are many different spells and you can combine three skill trees together to make your hero feel diverse, you are not limited in how many skills you may put on your action bars, therefore you ultimately aren't choosing skills, only trees. Of course everybody eventually goes towards the same skillsets, or rather similar ones.

There is a combo system in play which does help making builds a little more diverse. It works like this: If you fear the target before using this spell you will do more damage.

Then pvp is very much who initiated and stunlocked who first (no diminishing returns!) There are a few spells that will cancel out certain cc's.

The biggest issue I have with the skills though would be the awful passives. A lot of the passives are activated by chance. Such as being hit by a critical attack will boost your own critical attack by #. This type of random" mechanic is found very often on the passives. Then to top it off
recommended:
if you proc the passive too often it will disable it for # seconds/minute. One passive that is randomly activated disables if you MOVE. Extremely poor passive design.

There are also a few (thankfully not a lot) of self using buffs that last ~a minute and have no cooldown. Why bother. Why not make this a passive. Just extremely annoying.

PVE:
The game does eventually open up a bit
hoursPlayed: but questing is really the only way to go. The quests are mostly very boring fetch quests (especially early on). Doing every quest I saw between 1 - 10 I killed less than 50 monsters. I understand that they want to introduce the game to you via quests
voteText: but it doesn’t take a genius to understand that you right click seeds in your inventory to plant them in a huge farm where tons of others are planting.\n\nThe loot is extremely lackluster. There a few typical set bonuses

column19: especially in pvp. Boats have been done before in a mmo
column20: but seem to have been put together a bit better in archeage.\n\nMobs and spells in general aren’t very exciting. You can’t actively block
column21:
dodge or even kite very well. Mob interaction is far and few.

Overall:

If all you want from a game is a very large

column23: crafting mmo. This is for you
