hoursPlayed:
to feel interested in it. There's only the arena (1v1 or 5v5) where there seems to be descent PvP(and with current balance only few classes are represented here). Most of the PvP is just ganking where it comes down to who strikes first.

Pros:
- Non instanced housing where placement matters
- Good concept
- Good graphics
- Crafting system is okay. The best gear in the game is obtained through crafting aswell as a lot of RNG
- The game encourages playing with guild and friends
- "Endgame" is about what you want

Cons:
- Class system is garbage. A good idea but it comes down to a few skill trees being completely dominating.
- No bugfixed (like at all. Instances are bugged to make boss fights trivial have been there probably since release aswell as other gamebreaking bugs)
- Labor points system preventing you from doing what you want to (crafting
voteText:
gathering and even grinding requires labor points)

- A lot of the content of the game is only scheduled at specific times. You can't just do "what you want" at anytime in the game. For example if you want to do Hasla it's only once every 4 hours.

reviewText: Dont mistake archeage for a f2p game...\nArcheage is not truly made to be a f2p game. The f2p portion is a taste of the game and if you like it you will want to pay for the subscription. This is like the play to 20 system on wow but it is longer. There are ways around purchasing the subscription with money. Before I started paying for patron (the premium) I got a month free through buying apexs I made by different labor free gold methods. It was a hard long haul of small gains but 800 gold later I bought 2 apexs (premium currency) and got patron for free. After I obtained patron I made enough gold to buy patron 10 times over. It is possible but it is hard and requires alot of dedication and hardwork. After a while I broke down and started paying for patron for real money and it was well worth it. The only major problem that I have with this game is the current state of the server that I play (Aranzeb) and the reviews that make this game look like it is black desert. If you do goto play on the Arazeb NA server feel free to freind me im Zorzx ingame

reviewText:
I don't normally take the time to write reviews, but I thought it was important you understand ArcheAge. So you can think long and hard before investing your time and money.

ArcheAge could have been a very amazing MMO, but it is completely ruined by the cash shop and Trion's money  grubbing. You have no hope of getting anywhere without the payed account statis. Which you can pay $15 a month for (Which I have no problem with, MMO developers should make money off their product, just not expect to suck an endless amount out with broken cash shops.), or buy two Apex items off your servers auction house. My server Apex was worth 500-600g. Now apex can only be bought through Trion's webpage for $10. Meaning anyone using apex for a payed account, will be feeding Trion $20 a month instead of the normal $15.

With this being stated, the majority of players pay money for their monthly account. Despite this Trion still forces cash shop purchase with regrade charms, that only come from the cash shop and can not be crafted.

End game bosses are unoriginal and boring. Each boss shoots out some form of area of effect one shot magic attack. Which is countered by standing together the whole fight and casting a spell, that makes all of you immune to magic damage. The only exception to this is boss ship battles.(They are fun.) Bosses are open World, where only one guild gets to kill and loot it. Each with a one day repawn timer. Your faction or the opposing faction can grief you while you fight a boss. Even if you get boss loot, you are still forced to regrade it.

Regrading is a JOKE and is the hidden" end game in ArcheAge. I've never seen a MMO punish their players so much before for simplely upgrading their equipment. It is a system based only on luck and cash spent
date: where 99% of the players fail time after time
recommended: while the 1% get impossible success after success. Enough so where you just assume they are cheating.\n\nYou regrade an item by using a scroll and spending gold each attempt. Charms can be added to this to increase your chance of success. Each success increases the grade of an item
hoursPlayed: giving it a stat boost. Once you reach a certain grade
voteText: your item can not only explode and destroy it
helpfulPercent: it can fail and fall three grades. There is NO WAY to prevent this
votesHelpful: leaving you with only wasted time and money.\n\nI am very sad because ArcheAge could have be great game
votesTotal: but at it's core ArcheAge is built to milk money from your wallet."

reviewText:
I am going to share my story with this game,this review will be long but I hope to tell you about how the game was and how it is now so you can all get an idea of if you'll like it and where the game is going. And if oyu are going to read please do read to teh end,I don;t want anyone getting the wrong idea.

I was a Gold Founder for archeage,i supported this game pre-release and played all the beta events,and as any Founder will tell you the Beta was amazing,it was beautiful and it was fun. A huge world where you can craft,build,fight and explore with your friends and make new ones in-game. The beta was truely great and it was an aweseom time.

However,then came the 4-day head start for founders and this is where the first signs of Trions mismanagement started to show,there simply were not enough servers,and this was with knowing exactly how many players they would have as everyone playing had paid for the founder pack,and this started to show poor management. At the time most founders were annoyed about not being able to pay,I was,but thre were also some of us that realised how bad it could be when the game went to open access and Trion wouldn't even know how many people to expect,and on day 5 the servers simply could not cope,there was at most 1 more server added which still couldn't even fit all the founders in so on day 5 there were queues of over 7000 people waiting to get into a server.

Now don't get me wrong,the game is amazing,for those that don't know the game is originally made by a Korean company and Trions runs the game for NA and EU with their main original role being translation (which they still haven;t done completely) all the problems seen in the first month of teh game were down to Trions management, NOT the game.

After week 5 I stopped playing untill December,I had truely lost hope in Trions ability to run the game. But when I took a look at the game in December I got my hope back Trion seemed to be doing there hardest to make up for their previous mistakes,I had not looked untill then but I found out that 2 months into teh game they released a componsation package for all founders afffected by the ♥♥♥♥ storm at launch. They also seemed to have a more friendly relation with teh player-base like they did in Beta and Alpha.

And in the Summer of 2015 with the games 1st Anniversary Trion seemed to have fixed most of their problems,however they do somethimes make gamechanging decisions done by vote on polls without advertising the poll to the whole community.

Since then the game has been improving in general,and apart from some anger within the community about Server Merging Trion has not really made an massivly unpopular decisions.

The gameplay itself tis great,each race has a truely amazing story my faviourite being the Nuian,the combat is fun and different from a lot of MMOs standing comabt,this allows you to,and at times you must,move and fight mobile. you can build ships and dail the oceans,live as a pirate,fisherman,miner,armour,warrior there are huge amount of choices.
You also pick 3 subclasses to make your overall class and you can change them at any time meaning that you are not locked to a single class.

The community is great,I have only ever met a few people who are just toxic towards other players,even most pirates are friendly enough. You will be able to find a guild that suits you,and with my experience most guild leaders are very helpful and kind.

Overall I do recomend the game:
Game itself:9/10
Trion Management:6/10
Community:10/10

reviewText:
Best MMORPG i've played so far with the exception that you have to invest into the game.
At first (lvl 1 through 40) the game can be really fun. It is openworld, you can do anything you want.
You want to climb a mountain or upgrade your glider? no problem. You can equip you mounts with gear, and they also level up and gain special abilitys for movement or combat.

You can do ANYTHING in archeage without paying a cent, BUT it will take extremely long.
Otherwise you can invest $15 a month for padron status. I suggest you look up some forums about archeage being pay2win.

if you like to play for a really long time( or invest monthly) this game should be perfect for you
the community is also pretty nice, and the chat is also pretty fun to read especially the trial chat :D

reviewText: Archeage is not your typical mmorpg. There is a lot to do in-game that will keep you busy even during your downtime. the number of skill combinations are outrageous. you can grind the hell out of this game for years. Archeage has a very slow start, and can be sometimes confusing. you have to be high-leveled and  a devoted player to actually enjoy all the outsanding features that this game offers.\n\nI reccomend this game to devoted mmorpg players, but if you just don't have the time, then i suggest you try something else.

reviewText:
I have played the closed beta session 3 and got to level 30 so this is a limited review thus far, so take it how you will but within reason.

Lets start with the leveling experience first off, its nothing new just think world of warcraft style macro based skill combat but with a much nicer skill stree system wich I will get into in a moment, the combat might be rather rotation based however, thanks to how the combo system works it actually ends up creating quiet a few different viable combos to pull of, if it be a CC focussed attack or something towards high single target damage, the game allows for you to mix it up quiet alot and still be effective towards whatever your target. This made the leveling experience alot nicer for me as the game sticks to traditional mmorpg quest hubs, grab some quests kill 15 of these whilst stealing 10 of them and hand them in, the only difference here is that there is an over achieving system, where if you kill more than your target on the way back to the quest giver, you recieve a bonus for that or alternatively, you can hand in early and complete the quest for a lesser reward. It doesn't differ on the quest variety much though.

The class system is somewhat nice on this, at character creation you get to choose from a multitude of classes for all sorts of roles to forfill on the typical holy trinity structure tank/damage/healer and then off you go to fight. At level 5 you can choose again from the same pool, then again at level 10, every other time you level up you get to choose from skills from one of the trees, each move can combo with other skill you learnt from other trees, this made picking and choosing fun as it opens up a whole new window of oppertunity with personal strategy

The last thing I want to hit on before I end this review of my experience is the thing that I loved most about my time in archeage, the world and travel. This game has everything I loved about my wow days and more, the open world with no instancing and no loading screens, this is SO important to me in a game like this, the freedom to explore on my own terms if it be by my  personal mount that I raised from a pup (or kitten I guess in my case) or by glider and if your destination is across the sea you can travel by a large choice of boats and ships. One of the things that got me most outstanding features of this game is the player housing and land owning wich I feel most mmo's have failed to deliver even though its close to no1 on players requested features, this game does it and it does it very well but I will have to do an update on that when I actually do it myself. If you wish for me to explain in more detail any of what I have posted just add me steam and ask away :)

This game is honestly amazing and ground breaking. The class system, the combat, the sandbox gliders, mounts, vehicles, houses, farms, all amazing. Give this a chance, take some time to really realize why this game is so good

reviewerDisplayName: B L E E C h
reviewText:
This is nearly a GREAT game. Unfortunately, only nearly. Some of the problems are unfixable. My biggest gripe is: NO ONE TALKS. Even if you talk to another player, 9 times out of 10 they don't talk back because they're too busy grinding something whether it be gilda, crafting, gold or combat. For me personally, that's most of what the game could be down the toilet instantly. Without any regular meaningful communication with other players how exactly do players of this MMO actually relate to each other? Running dungeon raids together or by murdering you mainly. And I have no problem with PVP, in fact I am in favour of it but without any positive form of relating to players to balance it out this game really ends up, despite the wonderful structure it has in place, being just a boring grind and hoard fest.

Also, most  of the early-game's adventuring spirit was entirely anhilated by an unfortunate need to have to do a gazillion tedious quests to level up which mostly consisted of boshing mobs that are standing around all over the damn place like a bunch of cheap ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s, waiting for you to abuse them. Then when you finally have reached level 50 you've seen nearly the whole map and don't really feel like adventuring anymore. It is also then when you realise that even though you have reached level 50, it's the level 55s with the ♥♥♥♥-hot gear and the finely tuned derivative build who are still going to be butt-♥♥♥♥ing you at their whim.

What I would like to see future developers do is: Get rid of the grind altogether - it's ♥♥♥♥. Give us ultimate freedom. To do this, remove levelling. Start the game at the highest level. And get rid of ridiculously expensive/hard to find items - they're pointless and only encourage further grinding. Get rid of quests too, they feel too much like they're telling you what to do, directing you too much, and take away from your own feeling of freedom, inventing your own quests (or perhaps discovering secret/subtly written in quests). With all that ♥♥♥♥ out of the way, focus on one thing only - making a good end-game. Also consider ways in which to encourage players to interact with each other in ways that don't ONLY include grinding dungeons and killing each other. If a developer considers all these things we might get a good game. Archeage has a lot of great features, unfortunately they all come to diddly when overshadowed by the grind and total lack of meaningful relations between players.

reviewText:
I feel like it's time....don't play this game...please?
As many of these reviews I played World of Warcraft but due to high school I could not conform to a raiding schedule so I picked up archeage instead. Now let's get things straight: archeage had the potential to be the next World Of Warcraft. It has potential out the ♥♥♥- an amazing open world, great graphics, awesome class system, challenging yet rewarding skill system and much, much more. But at the end of the day and my 400+ hours (I played on the normal app before the steam one came back) my experience was ruined not by the great (yet slightly troll) community but by the fact this game is Pay To Enjoy. Some would say pay to win or pay to get there faster and whilst I have debated both with my friends I must say after my first few hours of gameplay the cash shop started to rear its dirty head right up into my face.

There are stats I could throw at you like the fact you'll never earn as much gold as a person who throws money at the cash shop but instead of going on FOREVER, id like to cut this short by saying that archeage could have been a classic game for ever but instead of being pay to play like every MMO should be with no subscription and no cash shop it instead chose to shot itself in the face.

So no don't play this game...unless you wanna throw loads of money at it in which case why don't you just ge world of Warcraft and buy the sparkle mount?


...P.S. To get the game to work will require at LEAST 5 reinstalls NOT AN EXAGGERATION (my friend had to do it 11 times!)

reviewText: rng rng rng what does that mean?!? It means random number generator, which by the way is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. There is nothing random happening here. This game is a trap. There are not enough digital laws to protect people from games gloriously programmed for your failure like this one. Archeage is absolutely setup around scaling % algorithms. Meaning the random number generator is not so random. it scales constantly and changes constantly. This is why there are no actual percentages in the game. Archeage is beautiful and has so many different elements it makes the game feel unending. Good right? Well that depends how much money you would like to spend. Unless you can dedicate and focus yourself to one element of the game at a time your going to burn through money and hate yourself and be broke at the end. Almost everything is upgradeable and random. Even your glider can fail upgrading. If you struggle making money ingame or know your the type to impulse buy. STAY AWAY FROM THIS GAME LIKE THE PLAGUE. It's gambling with the worst odds and a trap.

reviewText:
ArcheAge is a mixed bag.

On one hand, it's a gorgeous game. Running on a modified CryEngine, it features fantastic character models, outfits, weapons and mounts. It's landscapes are as vast as they are detailed. The ability to set sail on it's massive, gorgeous seas adds a new layer to the already played out genre. Who doesn't fantasize about being a pirate?

Player owned plots are a throwback to days where MMO developers brought a balanced approach in delivering the goods to their playerbase. The community driven market is nothing new but very much welcomed.

At first sight, it really seems like ArcheAge has the potiential to redefine MMO's for the better.


!BUT!


Then we run into their atrocious P2W model. This game is a MMO whales wet dream. Sadly this applies to both the PvE and PvP aspect of the game.  As an examle, the taxation on player plots is rather high. Labour (which is required to craft, which is 1/2 the game in itself) is such a transparent cash grab that it's slightly infuriating. Then there is the fact that North American publisher 'Trion Worlds' is terrible at communicating with their community and when they do, they often renag on their word. Lest I mention their biased community support leads found in their forums.

Ultimately, at the end of the day, ArcheAge offers VERY little for seasoned veterans of the MMO landscape. However, for new comers to the genre it may very well be the game that gets them hooked. As somone who purchased a 'Founders Pack' which is the MOST I've ever single-handedly spend on a video game, turned out to be such a farce, I'm compelled to tell the average gamer to stay away. If you REALLY need to play an MMO, renew your WoW account.

2.6/5

reviewText:
Archeage has a LOT of potential. It's a beautiful world thats somewhat rewarding to discover. With the housing and trading system, most zones are populated with high level players so the world never really feels empty. The crafting system is very deep, but it does rely on RNG a little too much (its a korean developer after all).

But this game is NOT at all optimized well. Even a high end machine will have some issues. The small # of PVE dungeons are glitched. Housing is a joke because of hackers.

And, furthermore, it's Pay 2 Win since the best gear is crafting and with RNG, you need to invest millions in gold.

I wanted to love this game. I enjoyed having my own thatched farmhouse, doing my daily farming and livestock tending. Crafting here and there. Going on trade runs. Trying to hi-jack the enemy factions trade runs.

What killed this game for me is its truly shoddy handling by XL Games and Trion. I won't bother listing what they did wrong, as that list is a mile long. Time after time they screwed up the game more and more, because of bad management. I mostly blame XL games, as on the coding side of things, a lot of the issues could have been fixed. I feel like Trion has their hands tied in a lot of decisions as well so I don't FULLY blame them.

Best example of bad management: the day the new continent of Auroria was released, where it was basically a race to build on 1 of 4 spots a castle for your guild, 90% of the playerbase could not log in. So the guilds the got the castle, it came down to luck - and there are people that prepared for weeks to do this and lost out. I stopped playing shortly after. Theyve released some new content since then but I am doubtful the game is much better.

BTW, I played this off steam, so thats why I dont have any logged hours.

reviewText:
IT PUNISHES YOU AS A GAMER, AS IT ASKS FOR YOUR CREDIT CARD NUMBER.

Played this right after steam pulled it the first time. That could say it all, but to elaborate a bit. AA is a game with great potential but like many other mmo's it has been ruined by 3rd party game publishers more interested in making another buck than building a community that they can milk for years to come.

The main issues in the last 12 months center on:
1.  Releasing year 2 content less than 3 months after the game made its North American release.

2. Hacking is ramped and GM's more than a few times simply unban hackers on request with a lite finger wag in their direction.

2a. We’re talking teleport hacks that let people warp clear across areas and land grab hacks(you can own land in game for living/ storage/ farming) these hacks also let them bypass the system as a whole and INSTO-BUILD  their homes leaving 50+ people scratching their heads as to how someone who wasn’t even online could grab the land and have built a house.

2b. The land hacking leads to land barons" who make all their money in game thru selling land. These are the people you see selling 4 or more pieces of land on a almost weekly bases.

3. GAMES LABOURS LOST or THEY HATE YOU AS A PLAYER AND THE ONLY WAY THEY WILL EVER LOVE YOU IS IF YOU GIVE THEM MONEY ON A WEEKLY BASES FOREVER. This is illustrated whenever you buy a pack like the one steam sells here. They generally have gear that is better than that which can be acquired in game for free. That is until AA staff decides to gimp that gear after you bought. This compounded by the reminder you need "patron status". Patron status is the "non-required required" monthly fee that allows you to own land; own but not keep. You must after paying the MONTHLY FEE
date: you need to pay a WEEKLY FEE as well in order to keep your land. Now maybe you get busy with life or you just decide to play something else instead? Then after 2 weeks you land is lost to you and the most valuable items are sent to your mail box
recommended:
after 30 days all items that the game recovered on your land that were sent to mail will AUTO-DELETE IN YOUR MAIL BOX.

(This includes item purchased from the ingame cash shop. That’s right all items in the game are fair grounds for deletion.)

Removing almost every reason to come back to AA ever(Side Note: This last May they have a “come back to AA” even which did nothing to return lost goods to former players. Instead giving returning players cheap gimped gear as a reward for trying to play again).

Honestly never played an MMO that punishes gamers to the level that it could be consider STEALING FROM GAMERS.

(FINAL NOTE: Dont even attempt to play unless you do your researh first. As of this winter 2015 atleast 4-6 NA servers and 4 EU servers will be merged into 1 NA and 1EU having all those people still playing on those servers losing all their land and having to start anew.)
"

reviewText:
Like many others, ignore my play time.  I downloaded this via steam, just so I could write another negative review among the masses, so that it the reviews would reflect the state of the actual game, instead of the Early Access reviews.  I played a Harani on Kyrios, as part of <The Soggy Potato Trading Co>.

Play as a pirate?  Kill your own faction?!  CARS?!  BOATS?!~?!  I'm on a boat~ I'm on a boa- wait a minute...*

ArcheAge had a lot of potential, and I was part of a group of 8 friends who decided to play the game together.  We all got to 50 and had a lot of fun, but it progressively worsened.  There were many problems that Trion simply did not fix, and I'm just going to write them as a list, instead of a wall of text for people to decipher.

1. Bots: After the implementation of needing to be lv15 to use the Faction and Nation chats, a surge in bots appeared, impending the ability to complete some quests in a timely manner.  I took a screenshot of nearly 100 bots in a small area, killing all the mobs as soon as they spawned.

2. Hackers: The most obtrusive problem with hacking exists in the form of claiming land.  Farming crops and trees is a main part of the game, so to protect your plants while you are away, you need to own land in the game.  To own land, you must have the Patron status(which is basically a subscription service), but sometimes people quit the game, or decide to stop caring about the land, and it becomes open to be reclaimed by anyone willing to try.  The problem is that there could easily be 20+ people waiting next to the plot, hoping to be the one to claim the spot, but it will be claimed by someone hacking, sometimes by a toon that is halfway across the continent.  It's a guarantee at this point that you can only get land by hacking or buying the plot from a hacker.  This was a problem before Auroria was launched, to which most land on that continent was claimed by hacking, and it remains a problem many months later.

3. Pay2Win: With the launch of Auroria, came an increased need of a material known as Thunderstruck Trees(can be broken down into Thunderstruck Logs).  These materials were set at a reasonably high price in the economy beforehand.  It was something that only occurred as chance to any tree in the game, but with the introduction of the Rumbling Archeum Tree Sapling, there was a large influx of Thunderstruck Trees in the market, and for a few days, the prices of nearly everything in the economy was unstable, at least on my server.  These tree saplings still exist in the game as something you can buy with real money, and while I do not know how much of a value they hold now, it was just one of many things introduced to create a significant advantage to those willing to spend more money on the game.  Patron Status already had large advantage over free players, because of the Labor Point system.  Coercing players to create AFK macros to stay logged in the game, so they can actually do something in the game that earns in game money.

4. Unbalanced Class System: Something alluring about ArcheAge was the relatively large amount of classes the game has, but in the end, there were only a few viable classes with specific skills needed to survive.  There were classes that could either 1 shot, 2 shot, or 3 shot, anyone that wasn't one of those classes.  While gear matters quite a bit in the game, the class has a much larger influence.  If you're wondering why that matters, then you're simply limiting yourself to less than half the available gameplay, by playing how you want.  Going out to sea, which is roughly half of all existing playable area, would just be you going out to get yourself killed, and probably your ship getting wrecked by pirates or anyone doing pirating activities.  Yes, that's right...  Your ship can #GetRekt

5. If you need a number five, it's there and more, but I'm done wasting my time on anything related to ArcheAge.  Unless someone else were to manage the game, and spend the time to really fix it, it will be a broken, unplayable mass of data.  Occupied by bots and hackers.  Floating in the void of the internet.  If people are still playing this game, they need to #FindJesus.

*That was the only humorous line, in the entire review.

reviewText:
Have played this Korean gem MMO on its own client for quite some time. Not overly, yet just as much as a connoisseur like me would want to, enough for shaping an opinion.

Sure, the company managing it isn't probably doing the best job handling clients/players, also in keeping the game clean from bots and whatnot. Yet I'll not take that too much into account, as I will more try to reflect on what the game itself offers.

The Koreans have indeed made a wonderful effort here - the game-world is beautiful, so are the models and graphics, the landscape and details. Even the music and the narration are very compelling - I also love the elvish-sounding Korean-speaking NPCs here and there. English ones are awful though, text would have been enough of a translation (would really like the option that I'd get to go full-out Korean mode and change audio language entirely - Asian voice actors are overall and usually far better for games and the like, with voice-acting schools far exceeding the West's).

As for gameplay, it does get somewhat repetitive, yet the environments and open-world feeling make up for it. I also love the risk and freedom that trade runs and piracy offer. Kinda reminds me of me ol' runescape days, stalking the wilderness. Classes are also varied, and so are the options for character builds. Even though I'd prefer even more of that - Diablo 2 style - it's quite a meaty system here as well, in comparison to others on the market. Crafting in-game is rather significant here, as it should be in an in-depth MMO.

Overall, I love the game for its aesthetics, and really do enjoy the fluidity and varied nature of the whole experience. This makes ArcheAge my favorite MMO aside Guild Wars 2, Mortal Online and Secret World.

As a game, I'd score this 7/10 - I'm not all that huge on MMOs. :)

reviewText:
Short answer: No

More detail:

They had the recipe for a brilliant game here. World, lore, combat and of course the whole flight/naval battles on a different scale from most other MMO's

Then the accountants got their claws in it. Or it might well have been designed to be a cash cow from the begining. I know MMO's, hell, most games are about getting cash from you but they don't have to ram said business philosophy down your throat. Everywhere you look you're reminded of it. The gathering/crafting system, mounts, gliders, property, ships all require either an immense investment of time grinding in the game or a massive investment of cash.

If you have deep pockets or a whole lot of time on your hands (though if there's many people with more time on their hands than I, I'd like to meet them) and like MMO's with large scope go ahead but for everyone else, don't bother. Guild Wars 2 has no subscription fee, not even a premium status with perks. The things they do ask you real life cash for are either cosmetic or revolve around increasing your allready generous bank space or numerous character slots. GW2 starts you off with five, ArcheAge two. GW2 you can increase to 69 (though why you'd need that many I have no idea) at most here you can have six across all servers. Plus with the upcoming Heart of Thorns expansion, you need only buy that and get the core game too. They are adding gliders and the return of guild halls means you can have your own refuge from all the terrors of the world without an exorbitant price.

reviewText:
(Played thousands of hours, just not via Steam)

Probably the best MMO of all time, certainly the best I've played in over 12 years of online gaming. It has everything I could ever ask for from an open world PvP game and the naval PvP I took part in was by far the most thrilling PvP I've ever experienced. This truely was the MMO I'd been waiting a decade to play while I was PvEing in World of Warcraft.

So why the negative review?

I've never been one to cry about pay to win, as a MMO veteran I have come to accept this is the way the MMO market has gone but TRION took it to a whole new level. I have never seen such greed from a company or such deliberate and obvious whale hunting in my entire gaming career.

There have been a number of publishers over the past few years that have tainted the gaming industry with their incessant greed and TRION are certainly in the running for first place.

ArcheAge: 10/10
TRION: 0/10

reviewText:
Don't let the hype-fueled positive reviews from pre-launch fool you. This game has fallen far from it's potential.

I joined up late in Alpha and experienced a sandbox with amazing potential, but dated mechanics. The gameplay was fun and I spent many hours through alpha learning the ins and outs of trade and farming. As the game launched, disappointment settled in because the land which was so crucial to success in the game was gobbled up. I continued to tough it out, slowly building up land for myself and alongside guildies.

Then Trion started making a mess of things.

In a game so focused around the player-driven economy, they continually made choices which turned the market on its head and took away the communities control over it's economy.

Lets start at launch. Trade certificates could be bought for cash shop currency. These items are needed to place and maintain your property. Whats the harm? Well being able to buy as much as you could afford in real money allowed the whales to dominate the landscape with massive amounts of buildings from the get go. This also devalued the tax certificates making it really inexpensive to maintain the land.

Another item...the wagon upgrade. The wagon is the critical tool to making money in the trading game. It allows you to carry up to 6 more trade packs and move at a greatly increased rate, massively increasing your gold payouts. The one item which could put your cart from 4 slots up to the max of 6? On the cash shop.

Finally, there was a rare material used for higher end items like these carts called a thunderstruck tree. It went for 2000 gold at one point. Then Trion put in a cash shop seedling which had an exponentially higher chance of spawning one. Within a day or two the price dropped to 200 gold.

The game is build on a flawed engine with many security holes, allowing for packet injection. This would not be a problem outside of PvP but it enabled an onslaught of bots and mods to dominate the real estate landscape, ruling out any chance of getting land beyond paying through the nose for it. Time and time again they claimed to have clamped down on this behaviour, yet the suspect land grabs continued.

This game has lots of potential but because of mismanagement by Trion and a terrible framework it has missed the mark by a long shot. The only reason this game has survived as long as it has is because there just isn't anything solid out yet for the sandbox fanatic to sink their teeth into. Once the rest of the industry rolls out it's sandbox options I would expect Archeage to fade to obscurity.

For now, I highly recommend not giving Trion your money for this or other titles. They have proven time and again that they are only keen on making a cash grab. No tricks, no traps, right?

reviewText:
Like many others, ignore my play time.  I downloaded this via steam, just so I could write another negative review among the masses, so that it the reviews would reflect the state of the actual game, instead of the Early Access reviews.  I played a Harani on Kyrios, as part of <The Soggy Potato Trading Co>.

Play as a pirate?  Kill your own faction?!  CARS?!  BOATS?!~?!  I'm on a boat~ I'm on a boa- wait a minute...*

ArcheAge had a lot of potential, and I was part of a group of 8 friends who decided to play the game together.  We all got to 50 and had a lot of fun, but it progressively worsened.  There were many problems that Trion simply did not fix, and I'm just going to write them as a list, instead of a wall of text for people to decipher.

1. Bots: After the implementation of needing to be lv15 to use the Faction and Nation chats, a surge in bots appeared, impending the ability to complete some quests in a timely manner.  I took a screenshot of nearly 100 bots in a small area, killing all the mobs as soon as they spawned.

2. Hackers: The most obtrusive problem with hacking exists in the form of claiming land.  Farming crops and trees is a main part of the game, so to protect your plants while you are away, you need to own land in the game.  To own land, you must have the Patron status(which is basically a subscription service), but sometimes people quit the game, or decide to stop caring about the land, and it becomes open to be reclaimed by anyone willing to try.  The problem is that there could easily be 20+ people waiting next to the plot, hoping to be the one to claim the spot, but it will be claimed by someone hacking, sometimes by a toon that is halfway across the continent.  It's a guarantee at this point that you can only get land by hacking or buying the plot from a hacker.  This was a problem before Auroria was launched, to which most land on that continent was claimed by hacking, and it remains a problem many months later.

3. Pay2Win: With the launch of Auroria, came an increased need of a material known as Thunderstruck Trees(can be broken down into Thunderstruck Logs).  These materials were set at a reasonably high price in the economy beforehand.  It was something that only occurred as chance to any tree in the game, but with the introduction of the Rumbling Archeum Tree Sapling, there was a large influx of Thunderstruck Trees in the market, and for a few days, the prices of nearly everything in the economy was unstable, at least on my server.  These tree saplings still exist in the game as something you can buy with real money, and while I do not know how much of a value they hold now, it was just one of many things introduced to create a significant advantage to those willing to spend more money on the game.  Patron Status already had large advantage over free players, because of the Labor Point system.  Coercing players to create AFK macros to stay logged in the game, so they can actually do something in the game that earns in game money.

4. Unbalanced Class System: Something alluring about ArcheAge was the relatively large amount of classes the game has, but in the end, there were only a few viable classes with specific skills needed to survive.  There were classes that could either 1 shot, 2 shot, or 3 shot, anyone that wasn't one of those classes.  While gear matters quite a bit in the game, the class has a much larger influence.  If you're wondering why that matters, then you're simply limiting yourself to less than half the available gameplay, by playing how you want.  Going out to sea, which is roughly half of all existing playable area, would just be you going out to get yourself killed, and probably your ship getting wrecked by pirates or anyone doing pirating activities.  Yes, that's right...  Your ship can #GetRekt

5. If you need a number five, it's there and more, but I'm done wasting my time on anything related to ArcheAge.  Unless someone else were to manage the game, and spend the time to really fix it, it will be a broken, unplayable mass of data.  Occupied by bots and hackers.  Floating in the void of the internet.  If people are still playing this game, they need to #FindJesus.

reviewText:
First of all I'd like to say all the reviews saying it's pay to win are completely exaggerated and more of, Over the top.

Also I'd like to point out I have more hours into this game than it says on steam. I was running the standalone but it's bugged a bit with windows 10 so I installed the steam version.

The game at first seems a bit standard normal mmorpg not entierly sure what you're doing or where you go. Boring quests at first but as you get a little farther into the game around level 20 or 30 things start to pick up. You get dropped into pvp zones where you can.

A. Kill people in your own faction
B. Get killed by people on the other faction

People complaining about the fact that they drop you in pvp zones is absolutely asanine. Plenty of mmo's do this. WORLD OF WARCRAFT is a prime example. A game that has lasted many many years and is still going to this day.
It's very easy to avoid fights. For example maybe glide away when you see a red name. Or... If you think you could handle it try and attack them! even if you're 9 or 10 levels below the player YOU COULD STILL WIN This game is heavily skillbased and is not 100% dependant on stats and gear. Those help but you can still do damage to someone significantly higher level than you.

Lets get into the Pay to win" aspect. Not once have I seen something remotely close to be even called "Pay to win"
The only thing I've ever seen in the marketplace is workers compensation potions (Potions that restore labor) FUN FACT YOU CAN FIND THESE WITHOUT BUYING THEM. No one is seriously going to drop their damn money CONSTANTLY on a game just to get some labor. That's wasteful. You could easily buy patron and get a subscription to pay monthly OR stay free to play and leave it on overnight to gain labor. Once again I'd like to point out you CAN play this game free to play but if you want the FULL expirience. Buy patron. free to play is basically somewhat of a trial or demo. Not all the features are unlocked. Hey at least this game lets you play for free. World of warcraft MAKES you pay a subscription to even GET in the game.

Most of the "Gear" that you think is pay to win. Is usually gear that people have EARNED in game I haven't got that far but I havent seen anything in the marketplace relating to any kind of overpowered gear. I'm fairly certain you need to earn it with honor points. People EARNED this gear. Stop ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ on the game because you're getting rek't.

Now onto the mob's

The mobs are difficult later on. Around level 40+ it becomes VERY hard to solo things. But it is possible with a little skill and planning. It's not difficult in the sense that it's unfair. If you're not killing the mobs later on. It's because you are not playing the game right. Formulate a stratagy and learn how combos work
recommended:
And don't just pick darkrunner because you googled "Whats the best class in archeage" and then follow some outdated guide to put your skills into. Pick one thats best for you. Because there is not just one skill rotation you can do. It varies depending on the situation. You have to think quickly otherwise you could mess everything up and leave yourself extremely vulnerable and possibly draw your last breath.

There is one issue with the game that I have ran into so far..
Bots.

I don't need to explain why bots are a bad thing in mmorpgs I'm sure you already know why.
But there neat little things to combat these little pests..

1. Report them (YES THIS ACTUALLY WORKS
hoursPlayed: YOU EVEN GET A CONFIRMATION FROM A GM THAT YOU GOT A "Confirmed Kill" YOU EVEN GET LABOR FROM IT :D) Chances are they will be banned and their accounts "Stripped of all their gains" according to the automated gm message you get in your mailbox for a confirmed kill.\n2. Kill them in pvp zones. Chances are they aren't prepared to attack you back some don't seemed to be programmed for that so they just ignore you. So you can easily halt them in thier tracks and make them run back to where they were before (Some of them even seem to break
voteText: standing at the nui statue doing nothing or running in circles
helpfulPercent:
That will definately ♥♥♥♥ off the bot owner.)

You can even own a house yes we all know you can own a house in this game. But the extent of cool things you can put in them are pretty awesome. You can even put chests in your home to hold more items in-case your warehouse becomes full. Put some furniture. Have a nice little cozy place :)

In summary including some other things not listed here is the pro's and cons list.

Pros:
1. Engaging quests and fun gameplay
2. Huge world to explore
votesHelpful: All zones unique in its own way with a small piece of lore in it.\n3. No flying mounts
votesTotal:
Just gliders. Flying mounts break world exploration. Why even have them?
4. Player Run Economy
5. Cool mounts.
6. Fantastic Graphics.
7. Complex housing system.

Cons:
1. Bots
2. Difficult and "sometimes" unfair mobs/strong mobs later on (I eventually beat them after a few tries)
3. Frequent fps drops
4. Connection errors once in a while "The gods have disconnected you"


TL;DR
Game is not pay-to-win and is really fun the reviews are over-reacting gaming elitists.
Bots can be easily dealt with by reporting (GMS even confirm the ban for you in your mailbox within 1 day)
You get disconnected every once in a while big deal. Reconnect. Stop whining.
Is a gud game go download it.

All in all this game gets about an 8/10!

One of the best MMORPGS I've ever played!"

reviewText:
I have reached lvl 20, I have made some quests and finished first dungeon/instance with all of the task you had to do inside for example: openning locked doors, finding keys, swiming to find lever, climb the wall, escaping traps etc. and all the differeance beetween boses and their fighting style and tasks you had to do to beat them was absolute stunning and very refreshing after playing world of warcraft since fiew years.

I sow a lot of negative revievs about these game that said it's pay to win mmorpg well I can't tottaly agree with this and I tell you why. It's all about labor. You get 5 pts per 5 min of beeing online for example to cut a tree or mine you need 10 pts per action with in my opinion makes all the collecteed resources very prized possessions. So it's not like other mmorpg when you just trow garbage away from inventory. Here every item counts and may be used by someone so you can sell it/trade it for gold.

If you pay 14$ for 30 days you will get 5 labor also when you are offline, but actually it does not matter so much if you just play the game. Here when you play your time counts and actually in auction house you can buy your patron status also for gold. I know when you pay real money you probably get more resources faster but if you dont you still can have everything like others but you need to spend some more time to get it

About clases and spells... there is SO MUCH of it. Combinations, combos, items - 14 lvl's of items with everyone need to craft it by their self.

For me it's a combination of old Lineage II and World of Warcraft. I recommend to everyone.

reviewText: I used to be a big skeptic of this game. Quite a few hours of gameplay have changed my opinion. There is a main story but I hardly paid any attention to it due to the almost overwhelming amount of optional things to do. Typical to any MMO there is a fair amount of character customization to start, then when you get into the game, you can buy your gear for a relatively cheap in-game price or you can scavenge for it or you can quest for it, already you have several options. There are infinitely more side-quests than story quests, and while there are some pre-requisites that are unclear to me, I'm sure if you do all the side quests in your alotted spawn you can find a million other things to do. Want to run trade missions across an ocean or continent? Go right ahead. Want to own a house and live off the land? It's up to you. Want to pull your riches from the ocean through fishing? It's up to you. Want to claim other people's riches as your own as a pirate? Don't let me stop you. You can live life however you see fit in this game, anywhere from a life of crime, to calling the largest castle your not-so-humble abode. It does take a bit of a pricey PC to run on higher graphic settings, I wouldn't even consider this game for Mac users, sorry, you're definitely missing out, but most desktops can run this on fairly decent settings. Even with the lower graphic settings, you're not missing much gameplay-wise aside from the shine of a fresh set of plate armor. The controls can be tough to get used to, but that's nothing new when playing a new game,  there are a lot of things to be understood about some technicalities, but when you get the hang of this game there is no limit as to what you can do, and if you get stuck, the community is incredibly friendly (outside of pvp zones...) and especilly helpful on the forums. I had my friend help me through the first few parts of the game, he has over 120 hours on his account, he's only halfway to the max level of 55 and I'm only a level 18. Neither of us have a house, a boat, and we only have the more basic mounts. There's still so much more to do, so if you don't mind, I'm gonna go get on that. It's free to play, so what do you have to lose?

I've met some great people on it though.. maybe they're what makes this game fun..\n\ni would recommend it to those who dont really like to hit end game, because there really isnt one in sight. best in slot gear is just simply is not achievable. the pvp while great is super gear dependent, you'll come to meet people that you just cannot kill regardless of player skill. if you're okay with that AA may be for you

reviewText:
Disclaimer: most people who downvote this do so only because I gave this game a thumbs up.

Well, what can I say...  This game has improved a lot.  I was around with a few other friends during the closed betas, but the game fell apart at release.  As of right now, only one other person I started this game up with still plays (occasionally).  So why the thumbs up?

This game's been through a lot.  At launch it was swarmed by DDOS attacks (yes, they were real), bots, spammers, insane queue times, and bad management.  They even took the game off of Steam.

Now, they fixed it up and it's back.  The economy is normal, the community is surprisingly friendly.  There is almost no reputable source of a wiki on the internet, so people communicate!  The game almost has the old WoW feel to it.  There's no dungeon finder, no cheat sheets on the internet, and no cookie cut progression, going out of your way to capture cool pets with good stats.  Yes, it's true that it does have the same flaws old WoW did (some abilities/talents outweigh others by far), but it's a tradeoff.

All in all, I recommend this game.  It isn't nearly p2w as most people comment on, you literally can only but gliders (faster movement), mount armor (so people don't gank your mount as easily), and land (but pirating and illegal farming can get you the same revenue).  The rest are cosmetics.  Tweaked cosmetics with slight boosts, but nothing p2w.

TL;DR - It's worth a shot.  Go for it.  It's free!

reviewText:
Don't let the hype-fueled positive reviews from pre-launch fool you. This game has fallen far from it's potential.

I joined up late in Alpha and experienced a sandbox with amazing potential, but dated mechanics. The gameplay was fun and I spent many hours through alpha learning the ins and outs of trade and farming. As the game launched, disappointment settled in because the land which was so crucial to success in the game was gobbled up. I continued to tough it out, slowly building up land for myself and alongside guildies.

Then Trion started making a mess of things.

In a game so focused around the player-driven economy, they continually made choices which turned the market on its head and took away the communities control over it's economy.

Lets start at launch. Trade certificates could be bought for cash shop currency. These items are needed to place and maintain your property. Whats the harm? Well being able to buy as much as you could afford in real money allowed the whales to dominate the landscape with massive amounts of buildings from the get go. This also devalued the tax certificates making it really inexpensive to maintain the land.

Another item...the wagon upgrade. The wagon is the critical tool to making money in the trading game. It allows you to carry up to 6 more trade packs and move at a greatly increased rate, massively increasing your gold payouts. The one item which could put your cart from 4 slots up to the max of 6? On the cash shop.

Finally, there was a rare material used for higher end items like these carts called a thunderstruck tree. It went for 2000 gold at one point. Then Trion put in a cash shop seedling which had an exponentially higher chance of spawning one. Within a day or two the price dropped to 200 gold.

The game is build on a flawed engine with many security holes, allowing for packet injection. This would not be a problem outside of PvP but it enabled an onslaught of bots and mods to dominate the real estate landscape, ruling out any chance of getting land beyond paying through the nose for it. Time and time again they claimed to have clamped down on this behaviour, yet the suspect land grabs continued.

This game has lots of potential but because of mismanagement by Trion and a terrible framework it has missed the mark by a long shot. The only reason this game has survived as long as it has is because there just isn't anything solid out yet for the sandbox fanatic to sink their teeth into. Once the rest of the industry rolls out it's sandbox options I would expect Archeage to fade to obscurity.

For now, I highly recommend not giving Trion your money for this or other titles. They have proven time and again that they are only keen on making a cash grab. No tricks, no traps, right?

reviewText: I used to be a big skeptic of this game. Quite a few hours of gameplay have changed my opinion. There is a main story but I hardly paid any attention to it due to the almost overwhelming amount of optional things to do. Typical to any MMO there is a fair amount of character customization to start, then when you get into the game, you can buy your gear for a relatively cheap in-game price or you can scavenge for it or you can quest for it, already you have several options. There are infinitely more side-quests than story quests, and while there are some pre-requisites that are unclear to me, I'm sure if you do all the side quests in your alotted spawn you can find a million other things to do. Want to run trade missions across an ocean or continent? Go right ahead. Want to own a house and live off the land? It's up to you. Want to pull your riches from the ocean through fishing? It's up to you. Want to claim other people's riches as your own as a pirate? Don't let me stop you. You can live life however you see fit in this game, anywhere from a life of crime, to calling the largest castle your not-so-humble abode. It does take a bit of a pricey PC to run on higher graphic settings, I wouldn't even consider this game for Mac users, sorry, you're definitely missing out, but most desktops can run this on fairly decent settings. Even with the lower graphic settings, you're not missing much gameplay-wise aside from the shine of a fresh set of plate armor. The controls can be tough to get used to, but that's nothing new when playing a new game,  there are a lot of things to be understood about some technicalities, but when you get the hang of this game there is no limit as to what you can do, and if you get stuck, the community is incredibly friendly (outside of pvp zones...) and especilly helpful on the forums. I had my friend help me through the first few parts of the game, he has over 120 hours on his account, he's only halfway to the max level of 55 and I'm only a level 18. Neither of us have a house, a boat, and we only have the more basic mounts. There's still so much more to do, so if you don't mind, I'm gonna go get on that. It's free to play, so what do you have to lose?

reviewText:
Have played this Korean gem MMO on its own client for quite some time. Not overly, yet just as much as a connoisseur like me would want to, enough for shaping an opinion.

Sure, the company managing it isn't probably doing the best job handling clients/players, also in keeping the game clean from bots and whatnot. Yet I'll not take that too much into account, as I will more try to reflect on what the game itself offers.

The Koreans have indeed made a wonderful effort here - the game-world is beautiful, so are the models and graphics, the landscape and details. Even the music and the narration are very compelling - I also love the elvish-sounding Korean-speaking NPCs here and there. English ones are awful though, text would have been enough of a translation (would really like the option that I'd get to go full-out Korean mode and change audio language entirely - Asian voice actors are overall and usually far better for games and the like, with voice-acting schools far exceeding the West's).

As for gameplay, it does get somewhat repetitive, yet the environments and open-world feeling make up for it. I also love the risk and freedom that trade runs and piracy offer. Kinda reminds me of me ol' runescape days, stalking the wilderness. Classes are also varied, and so are the options for character builds. Even though I'd prefer even more of that - Diablo 2 style - it's quite a meaty system here as well, in comparison to others on the market. Crafting in-game is rather significant here, as it should be in an in-depth MMO.

Overall, I love the game for its aesthetics, and really do enjoy the fluidity and varied nature of the whole experience. This makes ArcheAge my favorite MMO aside Guild Wars 2, Mortal Online and Secret World.

As a game, I'd score this 7/10 - I'm not all that huge on MMOs. :)

reviewText:
Short answer: No

More detail:

They had the recipe for a brilliant game here. World, lore, combat and of course the whole flight/naval battles on a different scale from most other MMO's

Then the accountants got their claws in it. Or it might well have been designed to be a cash cow from the begining. I know MMO's, hell, most games are about getting cash from you but they don't have to ram said business philosophy down your throat. Everywhere you look you're reminded of it. The gathering/crafting system, mounts, gliders, property, ships all require either an immense investment of time grinding in the game or a massive investment of cash.

If you have deep pockets or a whole lot of time on your hands (though if there's many people with more time on their hands than I, I'd like to meet them) and like MMO's with large scope go ahead but for everyone else, don't bother. Guild Wars 2 has no subscription fee, not even a premium status with perks. The things they do ask you real life cash for are either cosmetic or revolve around increasing your allready generous bank space or numerous character slots. GW2 starts you off with five, ArcheAge two. GW2 you can increase to 69 (though why you'd need that many I have no idea) at most here you can have six across all servers. Plus with the upcoming Heart of Thorns expansion, you need only buy that and get the core game too. They are adding gliders and the return of guild halls means you can have your own refuge from all the terrors of the world without an exorbitant price.

reviewText:
Don't let the hype-fueled positive reviews from pre-launch fool you. This game has fallen far from it's potential.

I joined up late in Alpha and experienced a sandbox with amazing potential, but dated mechanics. The gameplay was fun and I spent many hours through alpha learning the ins and outs of trade and farming. As the game launched, disappointment settled in because the land which was so crucial to success in the game was gobbled up. I continued to tough it out, slowly building up land for myself and alongside guildies.

Then Trion started making a mess of things.

In a game so focused around the player-driven economy, they continually made choices which turned the market on its head and took away the communities control over it's economy.

Lets start at launch. Trade certificates could be bought for cash shop currency. These items are needed to place and maintain your property. Whats the harm? Well being able to buy as much as you could afford in real money allowed the whales to dominate the landscape with massive amounts of buildings from the get go. This also devalued the tax certificates making it really inexpensive to maintain the land.

Another item...the wagon upgrade. The wagon is the critical tool to making money in the trading game. It allows you to carry up to 6 more trade packs and move at a greatly increased rate, massively increasing your gold payouts. The one item which could put your cart from 4 slots up to the max of 6? On the cash shop.

Finally, there was a rare material used for higher end items like these carts called a thunderstruck tree. It went for 2000 gold at one point. Then Trion put in a cash shop seedling which had an exponentially higher chance of spawning one. Within a day or two the price dropped to 200 gold.

The game is build on a flawed engine with many security holes, allowing for packet injection. This would not be a problem outside of PvP but it enabled an onslaught of bots and mods to dominate the real estate landscape, ruling out any chance of getting land beyond paying through the nose for it. Time and time again they claimed to have clamped down on this behaviour, yet the suspect land grabs continued.

This game has lots of potential but because of mismanagement by Trion and a terrible framework it has missed the mark by a long shot. The only reason this game has survived as long as it has is because there just isn't anything solid out yet for the sandbox fanatic to sink their teeth into. Once the rest of the industry rolls out it's sandbox options I would expect Archeage to fade to obscurity.

For now, I highly recommend not giving Trion your money for this or other titles. They have proven time and again that they are only keen on making a cash grab. No tricks, no traps, right?

reviewText:
Since it's been 4 to 5 days now, I'll give my review a review.

ArcheAge is beyond fun. I enjoy everything about the game, besides Housing. I've decided against quitting because... well quitting over houses is stupid. I LOVE ArcheAge, and that itself is an understatement. Sure theres alot of stuff wrong with it... but there's alot of stuff wrong with me.

Personally, I'd like a house.

But you take what you can get. The character creation is beautiful, the gameplay is fantastic, I LOVE gliding, the interaction with the world makes it an interesting experience, and the classes to choose from are... overwhelming... but more choice, right? I wont rant about what's wrong and what I hate, cause that's only 1 side to my story. While I do recommend the game I dont recommend certain aspects of it. And I'll state, I'm SO happy I took my time to calm down and give it another shot. I'm not gonna spend a bunch of my time thinking about a fun game to play when I have one.

Yada yada yada, blah blah blah.

In short, sure somethings are bad, but look at the good.
I'll go back to ripping things to shreds now, good day.

reviewText:
Disclaimer: most people who downvote this do so only because I gave this game a thumbs up.

Well, what can I say...  This game has improved a lot.  I was around with a few other friends during the closed betas, but the game fell apart at release.  As of right now, only one other person I started this game up with still plays (occasionally).  So why the thumbs up?

This game's been through a lot.  At launch it was swarmed by DDOS attacks (yes, they were real), bots, spammers, insane queue times, and bad management.  They even took the game off of Steam.

Now, they fixed it up and it's back.  The economy is normal, the community is surprisingly friendly.  There is almost no reputable source of a wiki on the internet, so people communicate!  The game almost has the old WoW feel to it.  There's no dungeon finder, no cheat sheets on the internet, and no cookie cut progression, going out of your way to capture cool pets with good stats.  Yes, it's true that it does have the same flaws old WoW did (some abilities/talents outweigh others by far), but it's a tradeoff.

All in all, I recommend this game.  It isn't nearly p2w as most people comment on, you literally can only but gliders (faster movement), mount armor (so people don't gank your mount as easily), and land (but pirating and illegal farming can get you the same revenue).  The rest are cosmetics.  Tweaked cosmetics with slight boosts, but nothing p2w.

TL;DR - It's worth a shot.  Go for it.  It's free!

reviewText:
Archeage has a LOT of potential. It's a beautiful world thats somewhat rewarding to discover. With the housing and trading system, most zones are populated with high level players so the world never really feels empty. The crafting system is very deep, but it does rely on RNG a little too much (its a korean developer after all).

But this game is NOT at all optimized well. Even a high end machine will have some issues. The small # of PVE dungeons are glitched. Housing is a joke because of hackers.

And, furthermore, it's Pay 2 Win since the best gear is crafting and with RNG, you need to invest millions in gold.

I wanted to love this game. I enjoyed having my own thatched farmhouse, doing my daily farming and livestock tending. Crafting here and there. Going on trade runs. Trying to hi-jack the enemy factions trade runs.

What killed this game for me is its truly shoddy handling by XL Games and Trion. I won't bother listing what they did wrong, as that list is a mile long. Time after time they screwed up the game more and more, because of bad management. I mostly blame XL games, as on the coding side of things, a lot of the issues could have been fixed. I feel like Trion has their hands tied in a lot of decisions as well so I don't FULLY blame them.

Best example of bad management: the day the new continent of Auroria was released, where it was basically a race to build on 1 of 4 spots a castle for your guild, 90% of the playerbase could not log in. So the guilds the got the castle, it came down to luck - and there are people that prepared for weeks to do this and lost out. I stopped playing shortly after. Theyve released some new content since then but I am doubtful the game is much better.

BTW, I played this off steam, so thats why I dont have any logged hours.

reviewText:
I feel like it's time....don't play this game...please?
As many of these reviews I played World of Warcraft but due to high school I could not conform to a raiding schedule so I picked up archeage instead. Now let's get things straight: archeage had the potential to be the next World Of Warcraft. It has potential out the ♥♥♥- an amazing open world, great graphics, awesome class system, challenging yet rewarding skill system and much, much more. But at the end of the day and my 400+ hours (I played on the normal app before the steam one came back) my experience was ruined not by the great (yet slightly troll) community but by the fact this game is Pay To Enjoy. Some would say pay to win or pay to get there faster and whilst I have debated both with my friends I must say after my first few hours of gameplay the cash shop started to rear its dirty head right up into my face.

There are stats I could throw at you like the fact you'll never earn as much gold as a person who throws money at the cash shop but instead of going on FOREVER, id like to cut this short by saying that archeage could have been a classic game for ever but instead of being pay to play like every MMO should be with no subscription and no cash shop it instead chose to shot itself in the face.

So no don't play this game...unless you wanna throw loads of money at it in which case why don't you just ge world of Warcraft and buy the sparkle mount?


...P.S. To get the game to work will require at LEAST 5 reinstalls NOT AN EXAGGERATION (my friend had to do it 11 times!)

reviewText: rng rng rng what does that mean?!? It means random number generator, which by the way is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. There is nothing random happening here. This game is a trap. There are not enough digital laws to protect people from games gloriously programmed for your failure like this one. Archeage is absolutely setup around scaling % algorithms. Meaning the random number generator is not so random. it scales constantly and changes constantly. This is why there are no actual percentages in the game. Archeage is beautiful and has so many different elements it makes the game feel unending. Good right? Well that depends how much money you would like to spend. Unless you can dedicate and focus yourself to one element of the game at a time your going to burn through money and hate yourself and be broke at the end. Almost everything is upgradeable and random. Even your glider can fail upgrading. If you struggle making money ingame or know your the type to impulse buy. STAY AWAY FROM THIS GAME LIKE THE PLAGUE. It's gambling with the worst odds and a trap.

reviewText:
ArcheAge is a mixed bag.

On one hand, it's a gorgeous game. Running on a modified CryEngine, it features fantastic character models, outfits, weapons and mounts. It's landscapes are as vast as they are detailed. The ability to set sail on it's massive, gorgeous seas adds a new layer to the already played out genre. Who doesn't fantasize about being a pirate?

Player owned plots are a throwback to days where MMO developers brought a balanced approach in delivering the goods to their playerbase. The community driven market is nothing new but very much welcomed.

At first sight, it really seems like ArcheAge has the potiential to redefine MMO's for the better.


!BUT!


Then we run into their atrocious P2W model. This game is a MMO whales wet dream. Sadly this applies to both the PvE and PvP aspect of the game.  As an examle, the taxation on player plots is rather high. Labour (which is required to craft, which is 1/2 the game in itself) is such a transparent cash grab that it's slightly infuriating. Then there is the fact that North American publisher 'Trion Worlds' is terrible at communicating with their community and when they do, they often renag on their word. Lest I mention their biased community support leads found in their forums.

Ultimately, at the end of the day, ArcheAge offers VERY little for seasoned veterans of the MMO landscape. However, for new comers to the genre it may very well be the game that gets them hooked. As somone who purchased a 'Founders Pack' which is the MOST I've ever single-handedly spend on a video game, turned out to be such a farce, I'm compelled to tell the average gamer to stay away. If you REALLY need to play an MMO, renew your WoW account.

2.6/5

reviewText: I tried to give this game an opportunity to redeem its potential, however, after playing for a second time sadly it is not happening. I had better luck in the European server than the North American servers. It seems this game is all about Marketplace. Some games have one but don't flaunt it. This game takes every opportunity to promote buying with real money. Also, You can't own a farm or house unless you pay to be a patron. I can't understand why the free to play option allows people to have those things. Oh, I forgot, The devs didn't develop enough land to allow everyone to have a piece of it. I can't understand why the devs can't make instances for houses. Other games do. What I mean is that everyone has the opportunity to own a farm or house, they enter an instance" to go to it. For having the ability to do crafting
hoursPlayed: one would think the developers would figure out how everyone (free or patron) could have their own place to call home. The game had such potential but now I would rather play a game that offers free to play AND allows everyone to own land."

reviewText: I love this game.... However, I am not willing to spend $20K in order to have 8K+ equipment score. (Boo you, you don't need to spend money it just takes time) Yes however some of us have lives and cannot spend 100+ hours a week in this game like Koreans, or high shcool drop outs. I love grind in MMOs, but this is outrageous. Another reason to not play is the game simply has no playerbase anymore. You used to be able to run dungeons and recieve a currency known as Gilda Stars, but as of late you no longer can find new players to run the dungeons with since that is the only way to obtain the stars. Because of the crafting system in ArcheAge you essentially have to pay for the subscription otherwise you might as well forget it.
